President rules out blanket 
Sonics down amnesty 
S pu rs 

NEW VORK TIMES SERVICE 
WASHINGTON — President 
Ford has ruled out any blanket amnesty for military deserters and draft evaders but is consi­ dering granting relief to a few limited categories of Vietnam era offenders, White House of­ ficials disclosed Friday. 
Ford said late last month that he would look into the possibility of a g e n e r a l a m n e sty for V ie tn a m war deserters and draft resisters after the was asked to do so by the widow of 
Sen. Philip A. Hart of Michigan. 
The President had called Mrs. Hart the day a fte r her husband died to offer con dolences and asked her if there was anything he could do for her. 
M rs. Hart replied that there was som eth in g — d e c la re an am n esty . 
Ford said he would look into it and 
Mrs. Hart made the P resid en t’s pro­ mise public. 
Issue 
The President reiterated later that he would exam ine the am nesty issue and said he had ordered the question studied by his administration. Many observers wondered if Ford seriously m ean t to reop en th e issu e or had m erely been extending a pro form a courtesy to a bereaved w idow . 
Ford has now let m em b ers of his staff know that he will not grant a blanket am n esty for d e s e rte rs and draft re siste rs. N either does he in­ tend to reopen his program of limited am n esty , w hich exp ired last y e a r, aides said. 
But as a “ g estu re.” as one White 
House official put it, the President is seriously considering taking action involving c le m e n cy for a few men who ran afoul of the law because of the war. 
One possibility, the aide said, was the restoration of veteran’s rights to form er servicem en who were wound­ ed in the line of duty in Vietnam but who la te r d e s e r te d or c o m m itte d som e other o ffen se that cost them their rights. 
Noted 

The aide noted that the num ber of these men was not very great. 
T h e aide did not say why F o r d thought som e gesture was necessary. 
But sin ce Ford first said he would look anew at the amnesty question, a number of observers, including a few inside the White House', speculated that he had been put in an awkward position by his affirm ative reply to 
Mrs. Hart s request and her public disclosure of it. 
Although Ford strongly opposed a blanket am nesty in the past, for him to say he had looked into the issue and decided to do nothing could give the a p p e a ra n ce that his pledge to 
M rs. 
H art had b een i n s in c e r e . 
Therefore, som e believe, he m ay feel impelled to take at least token action.

Carter plan: Jobs, tax cuts, rebates 

ASSO CIATED PRESS 
PLAINS, Ga. - President­ elect Carter and leading con­ gressional D em ocrats agreed 
Friday on a two-year, $3o bil­ lion program of job projects and tax cuts, including rebates of $1oo to $2oo for many tax­ payers. 
C arter’s adv isers and congression­ al leaders indicated checks could be 

 in the m ail by spring. C a rter also spoke of “ increased tem porary Social 
Security benefits.” 
B u t h is a d v i s e r s said r e t ir e d p ersons would s h a re in the r e b a te program and that those who pay no in c o m e t a x e s w ould r e c e iv e p a y ­ ments in lieu of a rebate. 
“ I think it’s a good approach to the resolution of a very seriou sly s ta g ­ nant A m erican econom y,” the P re si­ dent-elect said of the entire package. 
He m e t w ith r e p o r t e r s a f t e r a 

Belching thick smoke from its exhaust stack, a souped up tractor drags a 5o,ooo-pound sled down the course at the Texas Championship Tractor Pull Friday night at Joe Freeman Coliseum. Contests will continue at 7 p.m. Saturday and 2 p.m. Sunday. Tickets are $4 for adults and $ 1.5o for children under 12. — Staff Photo by H.M. Dean Jr. 

412 -hour m e e tin g with 12 top c o n ­ gressional D em ocrats 

They predicted the program would get prompt and favorable action. 
The President-elect said the o n e­ time rebate, totaling $7 billion to $11 billion, would be a refund on 197B ta x e s intend ed p r im a r ily to h elp lower and m o d erate-in co m e A m e r ­ icans. 
C a r t e r ’s top e c o n o m ic a d v is e r , 
Charles L. Schultze, said a fam ily of four earning $1o,ooo annually would r e c e iv e a r e b a te of $1 o o t«» $ 2 o o 
Schultze also said Carter also is con­ s id e r in g p ro p o sin g an a c r o s s - the-board rebate that would benefit upper-income taxpayers as well. 
Package 
C arter and his ad visers said the economic stim ulus package also in­ cludes: 
• $5 billion to $8 billion in federal 
•spending to create jobs and an ad­ ditional $4 billion for public works projects. Combined, these p rog ram s would create up to 8oo,ooo new jobs. 
Carter said. 
Schultze said the proposals should reduce the nation’s u n em p loy m en t rate from the current 8.1 per cent to between 6.5 and 7 per cent this year, 
“ hopefully at the b o tto m of th at ran ge." Nearly 8 million A m erican s are presently out of work 
• $4 b illio n in p e r m a n e n t ta x reductions achieved by ra isin g the m in im u m sta n d a rd d ed u ctio n for taxpayers who do not itemize. It was twit clear when the savings would Ik* realized. 
Under cu rren t tax law, the s t a n ­ dard deduction ranges from $1,7o11 to 
$2,4oo for a single person and from 
$2,1oo to $2,8oo for a m arried couple. 
The proposal would elim in ate the minim um rate and standardize the deduction at $2,4oo for a single ta x ­ payer and $2,8oo for a m arried cou­ ple. Schultze said a fam ily of four earning $1o,ooo could save HOO in taxes. 
• $2 billion in tax relief for b u si­ ness. 
C arter and his ad visers a re c o n ­ sidering either a 2 per cent increase in the investment tax credit, now at 
IO JMT cent, or an employer tax credit equal to 5 per cent of his total payroll tax, Schultze said. 
• M a k in g it p o s sib le for th r e e - quarters of all taxpayers to file on a single short form. 
Schultze, designated by ( ’a rter as chairman of his Council of Econom ic 
A dvisers, said the program would cost $12 billion to $16 billion in the current fiscal year and $13 billion to 
$16 billion in fiscal 1878. He said the incoming adm inistration will try to find offsetting spending reductions of 
$2 billion for 1678. 
He said the program would result in a budget deficit of between $7(1

Ford energy proposals omit gasoline decontrol 

WASHINGTON (A P ) - P resid en t 
F o rd sent C o n g re s s a b a r r a g e of energy proposals Friday but failed to in clu de in the list hts p o lit ic a lly touchy proposal to lift price controls from gasoline. 
F o rd ’s recom m endations a m o u n t­ ed to a sum m ary of hts e arlier energy proposals, ranging from decontrol of prices no newly discovered natural g a s to e a s in g fe d e r a l c le a n a ir requirements. He also said he would send Congress within the next few days recommendations on reorganiz­ ing the governm ent’s energy and na­ tural resource activities.

Hearst reversal asked 

SAN FRANCISCO (A P) - Patricia 
H e a rses attorneys asked a federal appeals court Friday to overturn her bank robbery conviction on grounds the trial judge made errors “ which all but dictated the verdict of guilty.” 
In a brief filed WU Ii the Ut Ii I S 
Circuit Court of Appeals, defense a t­ torneys Al Johnson and F Lee Bailey asked for a reversal of Miss H earses 
M arch 1876 conviction and a ju d g ­ ment of acquittal. 
“ T h e ju d g e m ad e a s e r i e s of e v id en tiary ru lin g s which all but dictated the verdict of g u ilty ,” the brief said. “ At every critical juncture 
; he resolved doubts in favor of allow­ 

 ing the jury to receive evidence of­ fered by the government and against allowing the jury to receive evidence offered by the defense.” 
Miss H earst, 22, is free on l l 25 million bail pending the appeal of her conviction in the 1874 holdup She is living in seclusion with her family. 
The appeal claimed thai the trial ju d g e , the late U S 
D int. J u d g e 
O liv e r J . C a r t e r , p e r m itte d th e government “ to introduce massively prejudicial evidence of other crim es that occurred after the Hibernia bank robbery.” 
T h e p ro se cu tio n in tr o d u c e d evidence about ap incident in May 

1974 at a Dis Angeles sporting goods store, during which Miss Hearst ad­ mittedly fired a gun to help two fel­ low fugitives escape 
T h e a p p eal c la im e d th a t su ch evidence “ persuaded the jurors that. whatever she might have been at the tim e of the H ibernia robbery, she ce rta in ly had b e co m e a c r im i n a l thereafter. ” 
M iss H e a r s t, d a u g h te r of n e w ­ s p a p e r e x e c u tiv e 
R a n d o lp h 
A. 
Hearst, was kidnaped Feb. 4, 1974, by the Sym bionese L ib era tio n A rm y , and later announced she had joined the terrorist group . She was arrested 
Sept. iii, 1o75, in San F ra n c is co .

Jan. 8, 1977 

H 
San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday January 8 1977 
Oregon governor eyes 
Turkish prisoner swap 

Oregon Gov. 
Bob Straub has offered to exchange any Turkish drug offenders convicted in Oregon for Joann McDaniel, a Coos Bay woman serving 24 years in Turkey for smuggling hashish. 
Straub suggested the deal in a private letter to the American am ­ bassador in Turkey, but lawyers for the U.S. Departments of State and 
Justice said the measures he sug­ gested may be beyond his authority and could be illegal. 
U.S. officials have been trying to get Miss McDaniel back to this country with a U.S.-Turkey treaty along the lines of the prisoner ex­ change agreement between this country and Mexico. An aide to the 
Oregon governor said Straub feels that process would take too long. 
Miss McDaniel, 31, and Kathryn 
Ann Zenz, of W isconsin, have served four years of a 24-year term, which may be cut to 16 years for good behavior. They were arrested with a companion in 1972 driving three vans containing hidden ha­ shish into Turkey from Syria. 
Dr. Cooper to step down 

Dr Theodore Cooper says he will quit as the nation’s top health of­ ficer when President Ford leaves office. 
A spokesman for the Department of Health. -Education and Welfare said Friday in W ashington that 
Cooper, an assistant secretary for health, is looking at several options for future employment. 
Cooper is a noted heart surgeon and cardiovascular researcher. 
''Dirty Harry" is no m ore 
Clint Eastwood, in Las Vegas, 
Nev., to prepare for filming “ The 
Gauntlet,’’ says lie doesn’t plan any more “ Dirty Harry” movies. 
Eastwood said Thursday that un­ less a really good script comes along, “The Enforcer" will be his final movie as Dirty Harry 
“ The G a u n tle t’’ will fea tu re 
Eastwood as an Arizona detective. 

Bukovsky enjoys quiet 

Exiled Soviet dissident Vladimir 
Bukovsky took refuge deep in the 
English countryside, in the village of Coleman’s Hatch. Friday. 
A 3oo-year-old farmhouse cottage, like a print of Olde England, will be home to the hum an rights c a m ­ paigner for the next few days. 
Released from prison by Soviet authorities in an exchange for Chi­ lean Communist leader 
Luis Cor- valan 
Dt*c. IS, Bukovsky, 34, ar­ rived in London Tuesday and after greeting other Soviet emigres and friends, retreated to the home of his 
British host, actor 
David Mark­ ham. 
Bukovsky was the first prominent dissident to tell the West about the abuses in Soviet mental hospitals. 
He plans to return to Zurich, where he was released, In about a week 
His mother and hospital-confined nephew are in Zurich. 
Am bassador takes up post 

The .new Soviet ambassador to the 
United Nations. Oleg A. Troyan­ ov sky, has presented his creden­ tials to Secretary-General 
Kurt 
Waldheim. 
The 57-year-old envoy then met with reporters and said, “ It is my hope to have good contacts with the press here at the U N.” 
The former Sov iet ambassador to 
Japan called the United Nations a good instrum ent of detente and added, “ Since the elections are over. I think we can use that word again.” 
Ile replaces 
Jacob Malik, 
7o. who was transferred to the Foreign 
Ministry in Moscow.

Sinatra clan awaiting word from rescuers 

PALM SPRINGS, Calif (AP) - 
Frank Sinatra called off a personal helicopter tour Friday of the rugged mountain area where searchers are looking for his 82-year-old m other, missing with three others in a private jet that was hound for Las Vegas. 
The entertainer scrapped plans to tour the mountain site in a sheriff’s 
Quakes to be studied 

LA JOLLA, Calif. (AP) - 
The Institute of Geophysics and P lanetary Physios is settin g up a w orldw ide netw ork of e a rth q u ak e - study in stru m e n ts to measure deep, deep down. 
A spokesman said Friday that plate tecto n ics—the slow motion of g rea t chunks of earth crust and underlying m an tle rocks—will be monitored for the first time 
The aim is better earth ­ quake prediction by study­ ing so-called “ deep focus" quakes as deep as 4oo miles. Normal earthquakes are confined to the earth’s crust, no deeper than 25 miles.

 helicopter. His son, Frank Sinatra 
Jr.. told reporters that most of the 
Sinatra family would remain at their 
Las Vegas home. 
“This waiting is brutal,” said the younger Sinatra, also an entertainer. 
"Until you get a confirm ation one way or the other, you bite your fin­ gernails down to the knuckles.” 
Missing 
Mrs. Natalie “ Dolly” Sinatra and three other persons were declared missing Thursday night after their private Lear jet disappeared from a radar screen 
The younger S in a tra said he believed the fourth person, previous­ ly unidentified, was Mrs. Anthony 
Carbone widow of a prominent phy­ sician and a friend of Mrs. Sinatra. 
Mrs. S in atra was flying to Las 
Vegas to watch her son at his Caesars 
Palace opening. Sinatra Jr. said his g ran d m o th e r “ loves to go to the shows and she loves to play the slot machines.” 
He added that “ the weather looks pretty bad up there.” Th? younger 
Sinatra arrived alone h a motorhome at the San Bernardino County sher­ iff’s aerial headquarters at Rialto 
Airport. 
He was joined by Milton Rudin, the 
Sinatra family attorney, and long­ time Sinatra friend J illy Rizzo, who flew in by sheriff’s helicopter from 
Palm Springs. 
Highest peak 
Meanwhile, two ground crews from the sheriff’s search and rescue squad were climbing Southern Calfornia’s highest peak, 11,5oo-foot Mt. San 
Gorgonio. A helicopter search was called off because the single chopper searching in the area could not climb above the 7,1oo-foot level near the wilderness peak. 
A sheriff’s pilot. Deputy Vie B rim ­ m er. said se arch e rs believed the w hite tw in-engine p lan e had slammed into the snowy peak at the 
9,ooo-foot level on the southeast slope. 
"W e had that plane clocked on radar into the hill at about 3oo knots 
(345 m iles per h o u r )," B r im m e r said. "You can form your own con­ clusions about survival." 
Brimmer said the searchers were equipped to stay on the mountains for 
72 hours and were not expected to reach the suspected location of the plane until at least Saturday. He ad­ dl'd that because of weather condi­ tions. they were not equipped with much rescue gear. 
Jet Avia, the firm that owned the plane, identified the pilot as Donald 
J Weier and the copilot as Je rald 
Foley, both of Las Vegas. 
Sinatra appeared Thursday night at Caesar’s Palace, but canceled the rem a in d e r of his one-w eek e n ­ gagement He had been told before the show that the plane was missing, a spokesman said 
There was another crash Thursday involving a J e t Avia plane. T h at plane went down near Flint, Mich., killing the two persons aboard 
A spokesman in Las Vegas where the firm is headquartered said both crashes were in foul w eather. Bob 
Bender said the five remaining Lear jets owned by the firm had been grounded pending an investigation but returned to service Friday.

SPICULES EFFECTIVE THRU WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1977 

 who, in a corrupt and changing so­ ciety, have held stubbornly to their fundamentalist faith. 
But a few’ weeks ago, a church of­ ficial sent us a signed s ta te m e n t supported by several prominent lay­ men. It urged us to investigate the financial dealings of their shepherd, the c h a rism a tic T hom as Z im m e r­ man. 
He not only is general superin­ tendent of the Assemblies of God but head of the 
5o-million- rnember World Pentecostal Confer­ ence. 
We can now report that the suspi­ cions of his dissident followers have some basis. 
The Reverend Zimmerman, a dyn­ amic man of 64, has kept hundreds of thousands of dollars of church funds in a hank that he heads. 
Land deal 
At the sam e tim e, he has joined other church leaders in purchasing 
IOO acres of land across from a pro­ posed shopping ce n ter, which his bank helped to finance. 
Three church leaders are acquiring the IOO acres for about $155,ooo. When the center is com pleted, their land may be worth up to $8oo,ooo. 
Zimmerman told us at first that he had no in te re s t in the s h o p p in g center. Yet the contract to buy the IOO acres across from the mall is signed by Zimm erman and two of his church associates, Donald Shelton and Mil­ ton McCorcle. 
The suave Shelton, who heads the c h u rc h ’s stew ardship dep artm en t, has also p u rc h a se d m o re 
■ than 
$6oo,ooo w orth of ac re ag e for the shopping center on behalf of the de­ velopers. 
The land re c o rd s show that these purchases were financed by Z im m erm an ’s 
— hank, the E m pire Bank of S pring­ field. Mo. 
Both the shopping m all and the church headquarters are also located in Springfield. 

Stockholder 

Z im m e rm a n has held a sto c k ­ holder’s interest in the bank as high as $16o,ooo. 
He now ow ns $1oo,ooo w orth of 
Empire stock, according to the latest available records. He is chairman of the board and draws $15o every time he attends a board meeting. 
Four other top church officials are listed as m ajor stockholders in the bank, with holdings that range from 
$8o,ooo to $16o,ooo. 
For example, the president of the church-owned Evangel College. Ro­ bert Spence, is a stockholder. Shelton also owns $8o,ooo w orth of stock, although he was not a shareholder at the time of his land acquisition. 
The financial conflicts, we found, disturbed Andrew Melli, the respect­ ed vice president of 
Carnation 
International, who is also a financial committeeman for the Assemblies of 
God., 
He questioned the heavy church deposits in Zim m erm an’s bank. 

Moved funds 
The reverend quickly moved some of the funds to other hanks. But we have learned that $14o,ooo in church trust funds were still deposited in the 
Empire Bank as of Dec. 3o 
Both Z im m e rm a n and Shelton spoke with us at length They stoutly defended th e m se lv e s and one a n ­ other. 
They insisted that not one penny of the church’s money had gone into the land deals and that audits had shown no mismanagement of their steward­ ship of the church’s millions. 
Shelton said he had arranged for the developers of the shopping center 

Jack 
Anderson 

 to buy the land because they had prom ised a gift to the church and because it gave him an inside track on his own land deal. 
Z im m erm an sw ore th a t he had nothing to do with the loans that fin­ anced the purchases. 
Promissory notes 
Yet land records reveal two pro­ m isso ry notes, to ta lin g $688,54o, which were executed on Dec. 13, 1973, by the developers to the bank. 
The notes are attached to docu­ ments showing that Shelton was in­ strum ental in assem bling the land for the proposed shopping center. 
All the deals were consummated at a time that Shelton's boss, the Rev. 
Z im m erm an, was the active ch a ir­ man of the hank. 
Sources familiar with the develop­ m ent co m p lain ed to us th a t th e church leaders misled them. 
Real estate sources in Springfield, 

Four other top church officials are listed as m ajor stockholders in the bank, with holdings that range from S WJXX) to SI 6 o JHX) 

 for example, said that Shelton gave them the impression he was arrang­ ing the land purchases on behalf of the church. 
The former chief executive of the 
Empire Bank. Estyl Sparkman, now of F o rt Sm ith. Ark., also told us 
Zimmerman had falsely assured him that he had no interest whatsoever in the shopping center development. 
No recollection 
Zimm erman told us he has no re­ collection of the conversation. "My life is in the hands of the Lord,” he said. 
Since its initial financing of the shopping center project. 
Em pire 
Bank has been inactive in the deal. 
Meanwhile, we have learned that the In te rn a l R evenue S erv ice is quietly looking into the finances of 
Zimm erman and Shelton, who cate­ gorically deny any wrongdoing. 
Washington whirl 
• Stanley N ehm er. formerly the 
Ford adm inistration’s top expert on shoe tariffs, is now wearing the shoe on the other foot. 
He has turned up as lobbyist for the shoe industry he recently helped to regulate. 
• The Freedom of Information Act was intended to let more sunshine into the dark recesses of the govern­ ment. But Rep. B. F. Sisk. D-Calif., used it in an attempt to find out who is opposing his pet irrigation project. 
Under the act. he dem anded the correspondence of m em bers of Con­ gress on the controversial $2 billion 
Westlands Irrigation Project. 
• It has leaked out belatedly that the Arm y subsidized expenses for military men and their dependents to attend a religious festival in Seoul. 
Korea, back in 1974. 
An A rm y sp o k e sm an ac k n o w ­ ledged that $2.(MIO was allocated to pay the expenses of military people at the festival, in violation of Defense 
Department regulations.

A fire that claimed the lives of three children Wednesday was mis­ takenly reported in the Express as occurring at the Habitat Apartments 
The fire, however, was at the West 
Avenue Apartments. 
The two adjacent apartm ent com­ plexes are located in the 38oo block of West Avenue. 
The victim s were T rinidad, 7; 
John Anthony, 4, and Olga Ann, 3, children of Mrs. Betty Ann Centeno, a resid en t of tne West Avenue 
Apartm ent. 

Continued from Page IA have the tax rebates go to retired workers receiving Social Security benefits, who normally might owe no tax, as well as income-earning tax­ p ay e r 
Turning to public works, Schultze said ( arter will ask for $2 billion in addition to the $2 billion alre ad y authorized by C ongress. He said 
Carter probably will ask for standby authority for yet another $2 billion to be used as economic circum stances dictate. 
Under the program , job training and placement would be expanded, principally for young people and other "hard-core” unemployed Tile program would give spec ial attention lo groups such as migrants, minori­ ties and Vietnam veterans. 
Carter also said the proposal would approximately double the money for counter-cyclical federal rev en u e sharing. The government now spends about $35o million each quarter. 
Counter-cyclical programs are de­ signed to flatten cycles of low and high unemployment. They provide federal money to create jobs when unemployment hits high levels for sustained periods of time. 
In Washington, White House spo­ kesmen declined com m ent on the proposals. House Republican Leader 
John J, Rhodes of A rizona said through an aide he could not com ­ ment until he studied the proposals in detail 
Rep Barber B. Conable, R N Y., senior Republican m em b er of the 
Ways and Means Committee, called them “a much bigger package than I anticipated." He said he is “ discour­ aged by the dimension of the thing.” 
"It sounds lo me as if Carter is 

 yielding to congressional pressure very early.” Conable said, 
Carter said Lawrence Woodworth will he named assistant secretary of the Treasury and will be in charge of his tax program . Woodworth c u r ­ rently is an aide to the Joint Com­ mittee on Internal Revenue Taxation. 
As consideration of the program began som e weeks ago. A tla n ta hanker Bert Lance, tapped by Carter to head the Office of M anagem ent and Budget, said he would reco m ­ mend a tax cut in the range of HU billion to $15 billion. 
Emphasis 
He said he wants the heaviest em ­ phasis placed on creating jobs and said a $5 billion to $6 billion jobs program would he too low 
* I

House, attended the meeting.

House Ways and Means Committee.

Judges disagree on worth of poll 

Justices of the 
Fourth Court of 
I ivil Appeals 

The figutes shown on this chart are the percentage of “ y e s " votes each judge received. Each percentage is based on the number of votes cast on each question. 

1. Attentive to arguments 

2. Applies rules of procedure 

By BEN KING Jr. 
Local judges are strongly disagreeing about the worth of a poll taken by the San Antonio 
Bar Assn. that rates their ju­ dicial abilities. 
And while every other judge in the 
Bexar County Courthouse has given a copy of his or her ratings to the Ex- press-News. lHBth Bist. Judge Peter 
Michael Curry said he's thrown his in the trash. 
Judge Curry said he threw his rat­ ing sheet in the trash because he feels the survey is absolutely horrible and a waste of money. 

Withhold data 

Currently the bar association has decided against making the results public until it votes on the question inter this month. 
However, according to several judges, the real issue is whether the poll was worth the $2,5oo the liar as­ sociation spent on it. 
Others question whether tin1 poll was a true reflection of their colleagues abilities, while some said it will be an invaluable aid in im ­ proving their competence. 
About 53o members of the San An­ tonio Bar Assn responded to the poll, which evaluated the judges in ll dif­ ferent areas. 
Fourth Court of C iv il Appeals judges, district judges and county court-at-law judges were included in the poll. 
Also rated 
San Antonio's three federal judges wbre also rated in the poll. However, they were unavailable this week. 
All ll questions int he survey calk'd for yes or no answers from the re­ sponding attorneys. 

Included were such queries as, 
“ Does he act fairly toward all liti­ gants and lawyers?” 
Most judges agreed the question asking whether they were fair to all litigants involved iii a suit was the most important. 

Bist. Judge James C. Onion said the poll does help the judges because it shows areas they should pay more cure to in the future. 

Ile added, however, “ Someone might use the polls in the next clee* 

One judge con ten tis S..i. 
Hor Assn poll absolutely horrible anti a waste o f money 

Hon to w hack someone over the head with it to win.” 
Bist. Judge ll. F. “ Hippo" Garcia theorized the public will probably be 
'most favorable to the judges who scored lowest on the polls. 
“ lf the law yers don’t like the judges, then the public will probably like the judge just that much more." 
Garcia said. 
Several judges opposed the evalua­ tions, com plaining the questions were too general or the poll was nothing more than a personality con­ test . 
Bist. Judge Franklin Spears said, 
“ I don’t think it s proper for lawyers to be rating judges or judges rating lawyers. All that does is promote bad feelings." 
Judge Curry said, “ What lawyers think of judges is not as important as what people think of judges." 

The presiding district judj^e said he 

 did not look at tin' results of his rat­ ings. “ Regardless of how I scored. I feel the same. I may have been the most popular for all I know.” 
County Court-at-Law Judge Caro­ lyn Spears said she believes she will benefit from the poll but questioned whether it was worth the $2,5oo the bar association spent completing it. 
Several district judges said the next logical step will be to have the judges turn tin' tables and rate the lawyers who practice in their courts.

Lake clean-up extended 

By DICK M E R K E L 

 c h ih , ix P M SS Ca pit o l b u r ia u 
AUSTIN — San Antonio got a new lease on life Friday when its deadline for compliance with the Mitchell Lake permit was extended to .July 1. 

The city, faced w ith a possible state lawsuit for non-complianee, also saw the permit amended to include new and clearer conditions it must meet iii the Mitchell Lake project. 
Both the new deadline and amend­ ment were approved unanimously by the Texas Waler Quality Board at its regular session here. 

 rile approval cam e without opposition alter the board heard statements from its own staff and a representative of the city.

Bird, Madia hit TW QB action 

U P R is s n i w s c a p it o l b u m a u 

AUSTIN — The Texas Water Qua­ lity Board’s action to amend the City of San Antonio’s permit for Mitchell 
Lake drew an immediate blast from two state representatives here F ri­ day. 

Reps. Roil Bird and Frank Madia, both of San Antonio, expressed dis­ may at the TW Q B’s action. 
“ We cannot believe the TW Q B would agree to extend the city’s compliance deadline for cleaning up the jake when San Antonio still has 

Group wauls tag on bills 

Texas,' urban counties want the state legislature to start putting price tags on tile bills it passes, so counties will know what effect they will have on their taxes. 

W elcom e for iAx 

Mrs. Lyndon Johnson, scores of 
Texas politicos and just plain friends will gather Saturday to mark the return of Ll I Carpenter to 
Texas. 

A “ Welcome Home Li/. Fiesta” in the Institute ut Texan Cultures will kick off at B p m. with a Mexican dinner. 

Emceeing the festivities will be 
Texas humorist from Madisonville, 
John Henry Faulk, with Mary Den­ man. talk show hostess, sharing the honors. 

Tickets tor the “ Fiesta" are $5 and reservations may he made until noon Saturday by calling Mrs. Aus­ tin Kainsev, 733 7823. or Mrs. Nelle 
Fake, 732-2738. 

Tin* Conference of Texas Urban 
Counties voted Friday to give top priority to balking a proposed lull which would make the estimated cost of implementing any bill a manda­ tory part of the legislation. 

The conference, consisting of representatives from the state's six most populated counties, met here to assign priorities backing various hills which have recently been pro­ posed. 

Bexar County Judge Blair Reeves said. “ When the legislature passes certain bills, we want them to be sure they know they’re increasing our costs. 

 not met the requirements of existing laws and permits," the two said. 
“ If the TW Q B isn’t going to enforce its water quality standards, the le­ gislature may again bi? compelled to step in and mandate im m ediate compliance.” 
M adia said lie instructed the 
Legislative Council Friday to draft legislation giving Ihe city three months to meet existing standards and prohibiting the T W Q B from granting any further extensions of tile deadline. 
“ At Friday s meeting, the legisla­ ture was accused of supplying a political solution to a technical prob­ lem when it passed bills requiring the elean-up of Mitchell Luke. 
“ What was not explained, however, was the legislature was forced to 

 liecome involved by the inaction of those responsible," the legislators charged. 
"It is appalling to us the staff of the 
TW QB and the assistant director of 
San Antonio’s Public Works Depart­ ment admitted to tile board the city has never complied with all the pro­ visions of its permit. 
"P u b lic works’ Mid Sueltenfuss also admitted there could be future instances of pollution at Mitchell 
Lake and still the amendments were approved." they said. 
Botli Bird and Madia's districts are on the city’s 
South 
Side where 
Mitchell Luke is located. 
They have been leaders in the fight to force Sun Antonio to comply with the terms of the original TW Q B per­ mit. 
Lo-Vaca gas sale is denied 

O p p o s i t i o n bad been voiced earlier by State Rep. Hon Bird of San An­ tonio, in a letter to TW Q B chairman 
J. Douglas Toole. 
B ird ’s letter asked the board to deny the amendments to the city’s permit and instead make San Antonio live up to the original conditions or face going to court. 
At Frid a y’s session, TW Q B staff members conceded while the city was in violation with some provisions of the permit it was making a good faith effort to comply. 
Wording vague 

The statement came from TW Q B staff member Paul Seals who also said some of the perm it’s wording was so vague as to make the staff unsure just what violations the city was guilty of 
Seals told tin' board adoption of the amendments would clarify this prob­ lem. 
Hugh U Yantis Jr., TW QB execu­ tive director, said “ I think the amendment will make it absolutely clear what Sun Antonio is lo do and by when. 
Historic nuisance 

" I don’t think Sun Antonio has done everything right, but on the whole the com pliance has been reasonably slow," he said. 
“ I don’t think the slowness of con­ struction is the basis for a lawsuit Ivy this board,” he added 
Seals called Mitchell Lake a "h is­ toric nuisance dating back to its 
•creation in 19o1." 
He said tile permit and stale laws calling for the lake’s rehabilitation were vague as to just what the dead­ line was for cleaning up the lake. 
Overdue 
"However, I think both the city and the state pretty well agreed it was 
June, 1975.” 
.Seals said the city was ordered to clear up the odor nuisance, clear the lake of odor causing sludge, divide the lake into two parts for better control, aud reduce discharge of ef­ fluents from the lake into tile Medina and Sun Antonio Rivers. 
"A s best we can determine, Hie 
/odor problem has been cleared up." 
,Seals said. 
Also, he said, Hie old sludge bas been dredged from the lake, but new sludge was a continuing problem r 

 lie also said San Antonio was i i i violation of the regulation on effluent discharges into the rivers. 
Ile said a lift station required i i i the permit had not been constructed, but 
Hic lake bud been div pled and control of Hie wafer was good 
Fo r his part. Chairm an Toole called the M itchell Lake problem mind boggling. 
“ It seems we’re asking them (San 
Antonio) to do something that can’t 
|be done," lie said 
“ W e’re asking them to convert the lake into a recreation area and at the same tune maintain it as an oxidation pond 
“ Maytie we should lot them drill a well down into the Edwards Aquifer and get water for the lake and send 
Hie effluents somewhere else ” 
Mel Sueltenfuss, assistant director of Public Works for San Antonio, a<l-

Friday San Antonio will be required to:

• 
Install a pumping station and have it operational for the north sec­ tion by July I.

M MUSX NEW S CAPITOL B utt AU 

AUSTIN — A Texas Railroad Commission hearing examiner has recommended denial of a Tejas Gas Corp. request to become a new gas customer of Lo-Vaca Gathering Co, 
Examiner Tom ll. Hill took testimony on the Tejas application at a public hearing 
Bec. 2 

In a proposed order of denial accompany­ ing his report. Hill said, "It would not be in the public interest to grant Tejas’ applica­ tion for new service from Lo-Vaca," 

He said granting of the request would tx* to the detriment of existing Lo-Vaca customers. 
He said there are other fuel sources which could Im* utilized by Tejas. 
I ii his findings of fact and conclusions of law. Hill noted: 

• Corpus Chnsti-based Tejas is engaged iii tile business of hauling and transporting fuel oil for Central Power and Light of Corpus 
Christi. It has applied for the purchase of 
17o.(1o(1 cubic feet of gas per day from 
. Lo-Vaca. The gas is to bi* used to fire a package boiler during winter months to allow for the transportation of heavy fuel oil by pipeline. 
• Tejas' need for gas during the winter months coincides with the times of greatest demand tor gas transported by Lo-Vaca and when curtailments are most likely to occur. 
• Other gas suppliers operate in the 
Nueces County area. 
• Tejas has gas production of its own. 
• The package boiler, purchased by Tejas prior to its application for Lo-Vaca gas sen ice, can be converted to burn fuel oil at a price of $15,(881 to $17,188)

HBG: Committee no legislative CIA 

WASHINGTON STAR SERVICE 

W ASHINGTON - The next chairman of the House 
Select Committee on As­ sassinations said Friday he will not permit use of hid­ den radio transmitters or similar techniques by the committee’s investigative staff. 
Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez of San Antonio, who next week w ill become chairman of the committee investigating the assassin­ ations of President .John F. 
Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. 
Martin Luther King Jr., said, “ We are not going to become a legislative CIA. I

 won’t stand for that.” 
The question of the propriety of the equipment and techniques to be used by the committee director, 
Richard A. Sprague, and his investigators was raised in a letter from Rep. Don 
Edwards, D*Calif. 
Inform ed 
Gonzalez said he had al­ ready informed Edwards in writing he will not tolerate any of the investigative ie-

 killed 
29 persons in 
Philadelphia last summer, a scientist says. 
Dr. Leslie A. Page, a microbiologist at the Na­ tional 
Animal 
Disease 
Center, developed a test he' said indicates ehlamydiae bacteria could be responsi­ ble for the mysterious dis­ ease. 

The U.S. Department of 
Agriculture and the federal 
Center for Disease Control in Atlanta have emphasized more testing is needed to confirm the development announced Thursday. 

In an interview Friday, 
Page said if his finding is confirmed. Pennvslvania health authorities have told him the discase could be traced to a large flock of pigeons that roosted on the roof of the Bellevue-Strat- ford Hotel in Philadelphia. 
Legionnaires’ disease broke out after a state 
American Legion conven­ tion involving the hotel in 
Philadelphia Ju ly 2o-24 
There were 18o eases, 29 of them fatal. 

 chiniques to which E d ­ wards has objected. 
Gonzalez’s stand is in some conflict with 
Sprague’s statements about the use of electronic equip­ ment and investigative, techniques; 
Edwards, however, may have over­ stated Sprague’s plans. 
Sprague detailed some of his plans at news confer­ ences Dec. 13 and Dec. 31. 
Records of those confer­ ences indicate Sprague in­ tends to allow his investi­ gators to carry hidden transmitters when they have individuals under surveillance and must be in contact with other indivi­ duals. 
Being recorded 
Sprague insisted investi­ gators will tell all persons if their interview is being' recorded. 
The $6.5 million budget proposed by Sprague for the first year of operations includes $4,4oo for two miniphone recording de­ vices, $8,ooo for two stress evaluators and $2,8oo for two polygraph, or lie de­ tection. devices. 
But there were indica­ tions the full budget amount would not be ap­ proved. 
House Speaker Thomas 
P. O’Neill, asked about complaints some congress­ men have voiced about the 
$6.5 million budget, said, 
" I ’m not going to comment on something that may not happen.” 
Gonzalez, while refusing to back off the estimate, said that he’ll take what he can get. “ If you can’t have a whole loaf, then you have a half loaf," he said. 

After the hidden trnans- 

 mitters were first men­ tioned. Edwards wrote to 
O’Neill that lie was con­ cerned that some of the assassination committee staff techniques might be wrong, immoral or very li­ kely illegal. 

“ Such procedures are to say the least inappropriate for use by a congressional committee,” Edwards said. 
Edwards also objected to public hearings. 

Gonzalez noted he was not the committee chair­ man yet and the Select 
Committee on Assassina­ tions no longer existed and wouldn’t until next week when the House reconsti­ tutes it. 
But he said he had given 
Edwards a prelim inary reply and intended to ex­ pand on his assurances that the committee staff would not be permitted to use 
.illegal techniques. 

CLAUDINE LONGET and attorney Ron 
Au$tin leave courthou$e after jury se­ lection for her trial on manslaughter charges 
Jury selected in L on get trial 

ASPEN, Colo. (A P) - A jury of seven men and five women was selected Friday to decide whether singer- actress Claudine Longet is guilty of reckless mans­ laughter in the shooting death of her lover, profes­ sional skier 
Vladim ir 
“ Spider” Sabich. 
The panelists, w ho will be sworn in Monday, range in age from 27 to 62 and in­ clude residents of this small ski village who were friends or acquaintances of 
Sabich. 
One of them is a service station owner who serviced cars for Sabich and Miss 

Longet, another played tennis with the couple and a third was a skiing compan­ ion of Sabich. 
Some of the jurors and two alternates expressed reservations about Miss 
Longet’s innocence, but all promised to give her a fair and objective verdict. 
The last juror seated, a young mother, said she once had an opinion that there was a chance she 
(Miss Longet) was innocent hut more likely that she was guilty.” She said she dropped that opinion “ in the past couple of days.” 
Miss Longet is accused of 

 shooting Sabich last March 
21 at the home she shared with him and her three children by her ex-hus­ band, singer Andy W il­ liams — Noelle, 12, Chris­ tian. IO, and Bobby. 7. 
Accident 
The slender defendant has maintained the shoot­ ing was an accident, that the gun discharged as 
Sabich was showing her how to use it. lf convicted of the rec k­ less manslaughter charge, 
Miss Longet could get up to 
IO years in prison and a 
$3o,ooo fine.

W ashington political arena during 1977 will be feature gu ests on major television inter­ view program s Sun­ day. 
S e c re ta ry of th e T r e a ­ sury-designate W. Michael 
Blumenthal, in his first half-hour solo appearance on television, will be on 
ABC News’ award-winning public affairs series, “ Is­ sues and Answers.*’

Ch. 5, — .Sen. Robert Byrd, 
D-VV.Va., the newly elected 
S en ate m a jo rity le a d e r, will he the guest on “ Face the Nation.”

B lu m e n th a l, who c o n ­ tends the U.S. can achieve a b alan ced b u d g e t w ithin four years, is expected to d isc u ss how th is can he done during his interview by ABC c o rre s p o n d e n ts 
Bob (dark and Dan Cordtz. 
President-elect C harter’s selection of Blumenthal for the treasury post has been interpreted as a signal to the b u sin ess co m m u n ity there is little to fear from the Carter adm inistration. 
B lu m en th al, how ever, is considered an unorthodox lib e ra l, and m any observers are assum ing a w ait-an d -see a ttitu d e on how B lum enthal’s conser­ vatism and liberalism will blend into an eco n o m ic mix. 
B lu m en th al has been chairm an and chief execu­ tive officer of the Bendix 
Corp. since 1972. He served as deputy a s s is ta n t secretary of state for econ­ omic affairs in 1961 and as sp ecial a m b a s s a d o r for tr a d e n e g o tia tio n s from 
1963-1967. 
Producer 
P eggy W hedon is p ro ­ d u ce r of 
“ Issu es and 
Answers,” a public affairs presentation of ABC News. 
Sen. Byrd will he inter­ viewed in W ashington by 
CBS correspondent George 
Herman, moderator of the weekly broadcast, and two o th e r re p o rte rs to be s e ­ lected. 
Mary O. Y ates and Ro­ bert Vitarelli are producer and director, respectively, of “ Face the N ation” for 
CBS News.

The Aces 
On Bridge 
By IRA G. CORN JR.___ 

If the baboon cannot reach the banana, he says it is not ripe. - African proverb. 
Roger Bates of Las Vegas w as in reach of all the bananas in his play of today's tricky game. And after a nifty bit of counting, not a ripe one slipped away. 
, 
North used the Flannery c o n v e n t i o n to s h o w a minimum opening with four spades and five hearts, a hand pattern that proves awkward in any standard bidding system. East’s double showed a diamond suit and 
South (Bates) ended the bid­ ding by his jump to game. 
West started with the dia­ mond king and the second trick went to East’s ace. East shifted to a club and declarer won the ace. 
A spade was led to dum­ my’s queen and East won the king for the defender’s third trick. East now returned a spade and West’s jack went to dummy’s ace. Dummy’s spade three was ruffed by d e c la r e r ’s heart ten and wh e n 
Wes t d i s c a r d e d , declarer had a good idea of 
East's distribution (after win­ ning the spade king. East had an easy exit of a heart or a club if he held either). 
So declarer led the heart seven intending to let it ride had West not covered Had 
West played low, the heart seven would win. the club king would be cashed and a low club ruffed with dum­ my's heart six. Dummy’s last spade would be ruffed with declarer's trump ace and dummy's high trumps would score the remaining tricks. 
In a c t u a l pl ay. West covered the heart seven with the eight and the jack was won in dummy A club was led to declarer's king and a low club was rutted with

9 5-4 and dummy had no trouble scoring the last three tricks.

Do not let the excellent spade holding lead you to an over­ bid of three spades. This is still a minimum opening and a single raise is quite enough.

Cuban exile leader i slain 

COMPILED PROM WIRE SERVICES 

MIAMI — Juan Jose 
P cruyero, who took part in the Bay of Pigs invasion and later be­ came a leader of Mia- m i’S anti-Castro Cuban exiles, was assassinat­ ed Friday as he left his home. 
Police said Peruyero, in his mid 4os, was sunned down by two men who ap­ parently had been waiting for him to step outside. He died about two hours later at Jackson Memorial Ho­ spital. 
No arrests were made, but police searched for two 
Latin men seen in the area by witnesses. 
A friend. Raymond Mo­ lina. claimed the shooting was “ another Castro exe­ cution. Castro’s executing those opposed to commun­ ism and to his regime.” 

D ebris from lanker found 

BOSTON - The Coast 
Guard found two life jack­ ets and other debris from the missing oil tanker 
Grand Zenith, indicating that the vessel has sunk, a spokesman said. There was no sign of any of the tanker’s .‘18 crewmen. 
The tanker carried a 
Chinese crew from Taiwan and eight million gallons of heavy oil. The captain. T K. 
Tsou, has 3o years exper­ ience at sea. i.

Maul fund tally 

CHICAGO — Two inde­ pendent Democrats are demanding a full account­ ing of party funds that re­ mains seeret 18 days after 
Mayor Richard J. Daley’s death. 
It would be the first full disclosure of the Chicago 
Democratic organization's tightly guarded finances since Daley took over the purse strings 23 years ago.

M ana gin g Editor 

City’s fiscal policy for the long term 

San Antonians pay 11.1 per cent of their city budget funds for b o rro w in g debt. T h a t is about the same percentage as 
American taxpayers dig up to service the national debt. 
Credit is a service all of us use and it s e rv e s well when excesses are avoided. 
But San Antonians pay a bit more than others because the 
City of San Antonio has its fis­ cal year on backwards. The c i­ ty collects its taxes at the year end. It is the only m ajor city — and likely the only city of any size — to do that. 
City 
Council has asked voters for permission to turn it around. That proposal is on next Saturday’s ballot. 
T h e r e will be d e t a ils to work out. Funding a 17-month budget year in order to make the turn-around so that funds are collected before they are spent may have to be done in stages. But the property tax, of existing revenue sources, ap­ pears the likely place to put the c a t c h - u p bite. A bond issu e could do it, too, but that would likely cost much more. 
Since savings is one reason to m a k e the c h a n g e , we s h o u ld n ’t buy the c o s t l i e r package. 
P l a n n e r s should t a k e the trend another step ahead. 

San Antonio is o b lig a te d under p r e s e n t bond d e b ts through the year 2ooo. Until 
1986, debt s e r v i c e c o sts run above $1o million a year. This year the payment on principal and interest will be $13,6o1,652. 
Next year the tab will be a little over $14 million and continue downward, going u nd er $1o m illion a f t e r the 
1985 installment 
If pay-as-you-go is good for the general fund it should have som e b en efits for lo n g -term spending. Capital funds are in­ vested in permanent facilities and it is logical to spread some of the load to future taxpayers who will use them. 
But it m a k e s sense to a c ­ quire a capital funds account over the years, an endowment that earns money. Things paid for with loans with 2o or 3o year pav-out term s cost about twice as much as things paid with cash or shorter-term loans. 
To do that is politically dif­ ficult. Indeed, the city charter would have to be changed to allow it. Charter term s call for using surplus funds to retire debt or cut taxes. 
But while council figu res how to turn the tax y ea r a r ­ ound, they should e n t e r t a in proposals along the sam e lines for borrowing. 
Soft-w orded resolution asks legislature to repair dam age 

The sick-leave fuss laid on 
City Hall by tilt* last legislative session has to be resolved at the next session. 

Now that the scope of the p r o b l e m it c a u s e d is b ein g m a d e a p p a r e n t to all c o n ­ cerned — including the people who pay the taxes — only the d etails rem a in to be worked out. 

So City Council's resolution, adopted Thursday, was a soft word instead of a tough one sent to the legislative delega­ tion from Bexar. 

Last year’s budget included a caution to City Council that nobody knew what financial liability the law imposed upon the city under the unlimited sick-leave plan. The budget al­ lowed $2oo,ooo. The liability turned out to be, for that year, about three times that amount 
— and rising. 

A v a lu a b le lesson can e m e r g e from the e x p e rie n c e that produced the law. First, there was in effectiv e liaison between council and l e g is l a ­ tors. Then there was bad r e ­ search and the faulty con clu ­ sions reached from it. Council and at least so m e of the legislators were caught in the trap, though the principle of unlimited sick-leave accrual is an unsupportable part of job benefits, anyway. 
The soft-worded resolution was designed to acknowledge that legislators did more m is­ c h ief than they rea liz ed because they were told that the law would save money for the city and solve a staffing prob­ lem for two city departments. 
Now they know better and will correct tin* flaw because they should -— and because failure to do so is a p olitical tim e bomb for them.

Hep. B en n ie B o c k of New

Barbarism is back 

Sir: To televise the com ing execu­ tion is unthinkable. 
Not too long ago in England and over Europe, executions were public and the mob began gathering the night before and fought for the best places for a good view. 
Som etim es there was a bonus of a fight and maybe a death among the watchers. Of course, it was more amusing if it were a Raleigh or an 
Essex, but even a poor farm er who had had a bad year and could not pay his rent. a pig and two sacks of po­ tatoes. would furnish a good sp ecta­ cle until so m e th in g b e tte r c a m e along. 
The big thrill cam e after the hang­ ing when they were drawn and quar­ tered. In early Rome the gladiators walked to certain death in tin' arena. 
Thum bs up? Thum bs down. Why not build a grandstand and sell seats? 
Art* these the days of Elizabeth I or the late 2oth century? 
Edna Hohan 
Dismayed by council action 

Sir. I, too. was dismayed, as was 
VV. ll. McOhesneg (Letters. Dec. 31). that City Council passed a resolution against the selling of a South Africa gold coin. i.e. F re e Enterprise. Why not a resolution against giant U.S. co rp o ra tio n s m a n u fa c tu rin g th e ir products in foreign countries at slave wages and selling them in the U.S. at sky high prices? 
Banning tin* South Africa gold coin sales ; denies Hie U S seller his profit as does selling U.S. foreign made products denies the U S laborer his wages. City Council recognizes the problem of the high ut Hit > costs fur the poor and elderly yet hacks the attempt ta move federal offices and waste the tax payers money. They didn t pass a resolution condemning the waste of millions to investigate the Kennedy and King assassinations while San Antonians go lo bed cold and hungry. T h ey c erta in ly have misguided priorities. 
Incidently, your headline story on 
C arter's hiring freeze was downright comical. The space wasted printing it could have been used for a profitable advertisem ent 
The idea behind a freeze is like saying you made money because a certain stock dropped and you didn t own any of it. 
Leonard Dallas

 sideration, is to put limits on fines and require towns that use state highways as speed traps to split the fines with the state for highway uses. 

Bock said purpose of his bill is to assure greater uniformity in fines for speed ing and to help the highway fund, He has a good point.

Brown lacks war know-how 

WASHINGTON — Jim in y 
C a r t e r ’s c h o ic e of Harold 
Brown a s tin* next secretary of defense brings back to tin* 
Pentagon a M c N am a ra -c ra apparatchik who knows all there is to know about nuclear physics and theoretical wea­ pons technology arid m anage­ ment in the abstract — and not much about war. 
T h is is the gloom y view of old 
P e n ta g o n h an d s who r e m e m b e r 
Brown IO years ago as the abrupt, a b r a s iv e , e v e n tu a lly a r r o g a n t 
33-year-old "whiz kid” who, as dir­ ector of defense research and en* gitteentig, third highest defense of­ ficial under M cN am ara, earned Ills nicknam e of " D r . No” by slapping down generals and adm irals unwise enough to oppose Brow u s theories with some of the intractable practi­ calities of war, 
“ It is B ro w n ’s belief — no, his conviction," said an officer who re­ c a l l s him during h is e ig h t-y e a r tour. “ that anything that eun’t be scientifically quantified isn t worth 

 taking into consideration.” 
“ Ile thinks technology can solve a n y th in g ," said an oth er g en era l, 
“ no m atter whether the solution is ans use to the man on the battlefield or not.” 
Harold Brown graduated with top honors and Phi Beta Kappa from 
Columbia University at age 17. At 
21. he won a doctorate with distinc­ tion in nuclear physics. 
The first scientist and technocrat to bicorne secretary of defense. Dr. 
Brown brings a som ew hat mixed track-record to his job 

His record 

Past policies and p ro jects with which h«* has been associated in­ clude several nam es of ill omen; 
• One of the McNamara regim e's costliest failures, the T F X all-ser­ vice fighter, the (lying Ed st*) which spun in on its innumerable im prac­ ticalities. was Brow n’s adam antly defended idea 
• 
The so-called "to ta l package procurement” concept under which the costs of warships and especially the t ’5*A transport aircraft soared astronomically in tho late Binits was 

Col. 
Robert D. 
Heinl Jr. 

 a n o th er of Dr. B ro w n ’s m a n a g e ­ ment innovations. 
• The suicidal theory of "m u tu al assured d eterren ce,” under which 
Hie United States voluntarily relin­ quished strategic’ nuc lear superior­ ly to Russia found Brown among its advocates. 
• 
T he " M c N a m a r a L in e ” — a mult ibi I lio n -d ollar Viet n am * w ar sensor harrier along the D M / that- r e g is te re d w a te r b u ffa lo hut a l­ low cd Hanoi’s regiments to march through — — has also been a sso ­ ciated with Brown’s era and philo­ sophy* 

Going behind this somewhat con­ troversial past performance (which likewise included original sponsor­ ship of the B l s u p c r b o m b e r ). a 
In e v ita b le q u e stio n a r i s e s us to 

 wheftier this brilliant, self assured te c h n o c r a t is th e m a n th e administration ami the Defense De­ partment really need today. 

At this tim e, for exam ple, under the nuclear um brella, conventional weapons and conventional, gener­ al-purpose forces (w hich account for over two-thirds of the defense budget) require more of a defense s e c r e ta r y ’s attention than the by­ zantine intricacies of nuclear theory which are Brown’s forte. 

R ebuilding a Navy which, with 
Harold Brow n at his side. Robert S. 
M cNamara allowed to run down. is the m ost p r e s s in g p ro b le m that confronts a new defense secretary. 
Y et B ro w n is r e m e m b e r e d as having bt*en anything but sympath­ etic to the claim s of the Navy, to naval weapons luther than the Po­ laris m issile), and to the national requirement for a blue-water, m a r­ itime strateg y . 
In th e se d a y s of a ll-v o lu n te e r forces, leadership and k»*en sensiti- city to the human side of national defense are prim e n ecessities for the top man in the Pentagon 
But officers who served under Dr, 

Brown during his lour as secretary of the air force (1965-1969) recall him as seem ingly oblivious ( dis­ d a in fu l.’ ’ re c a lle d a g e n e r a l > of people in uniform. 

Attitude 
This. to be sure, was the civilian style of the Kennedy*Johnson days toward the military. Being rude to generals and adm irals proved and demonstrated the dogma of civilian supremacy.

R. Sch lesin ger and Donald Rums- fleld, have demonstrated.

Problem of aliens goes to 
Carter 

WASHINGTON - President 
Ford's ski-slope invitation to 
Puerto Rico to become the 51st 
State was the most sudden and surprising notion he has had s in c e he lib e r a te d E a s t e r n 
Europe from the Soviet Union, but it has certain possible ad­ vantages. 
It could, but probably won’t, make 
W ashington think ag a in about its immigration policy, which is a m ess; abou t the C a r ib b e a n is la n d s in general, which arc beautiful jungles of economic and racial tension; and about tin* awkward and even a la rm ­ ing econom ic, social and stra te g ic problems of our relations with Mexi­ co and Panama. All this and Cuba too is some challenge! 
Tho main fact about the movement of people into the Continental United 
States is that it is out of control. 
E a c h y e a r , m o r e ille g a l a lie n s com e into the United States, and re­ main here. than legal aliens. Even the official figures and estim ates are staggering. 
Illegal aliens 
T h e Im m igration and N aturaliza­ tion S e rv ice of the D e p a rtm e n t of 
Ju stice estim ates that there are now between six and eight million illegal aliens residing perm anently in the 
United States — roughly as many as the total n u m ber of unemployed in the nation at the beginning of 1977. 
These are estim ates, but there are some hard facts. 
In fiscal year 1975, 655,814 illegal aliens were arrested and deported without formal hearings, and 23,438 w ere d ep o rted a f t e r .jud icial p ro ­ ceedings, most of the from Mexico. 
But this is a revolv ing door. The las­ ter they are deportered. the faster they return. 
M exico had a population of ju st fewer than 29 million in 1945. It now h as a population of m o re than 69 million, with an unemployment rate past 29 per cent and no effective un­ employment insurance. 
IOO million 
By official estim ates. M exico will have a population o f more than 199 million at the end of the c e n tu r y ------- form er President Echeverria told me he e x p e c te d the fig u r e would be nearer to 127 million — so this is an increasing problem, and there is no wall high enough along a 2.999-mile border that can prevent m igration from a poor country to a rich one. 
The movement of legal im m igrants is a different and m ore m anageable question. This is determined by Con­ gress. 
Congress established a quota sys­ tem which until 1965 followed the trend of im migration in the first half of this century — favoring applicants from Western and Eastern Europe. 
Since 1965, different quotas have been applied to Latin A m erica and 
Asia. and the offieial figures for fis­ cal 1975 indicate a dram atic shift in the human traffic from abroad. 
F o r e x a m p le, 62.ooo legal im m i­ g rants from Mexico in fiscal ‘75 — m o r e than th e total from B r ita in 
(12.999). G erm a n y (5.999), F r a n c e 
(2 .9 9 9 ), 
G r e e c e 
(1 9 .o 9 o ) . 
Italy 
( I I . (Mid), and Portugal (11.ooo).

Suggestion 
President F o rd ’s suggestion of sta­ tehood for Puerto Rico did not affect this pattern. 
As citizens of the United S tates. 
Puerto Ricans have the sam e right of movement into the continental United 
States as the citizens of any state in^ the Union. 
But Ford ignored the larger ques­ tion that m ust be faced by P r e s i ­ d en t-e le ct C u rte r in d e fin in g th e economic and social problems of the future: 
How to d eal w ith the unemployment problems when there are more illegal aliens in the country than unemployed? 
How to analyze the effect on this nation of the shifting pattern of im ­ m ig r a tio n fro m E u ro p o to L atin , 
America and Asia? 
And maybe inure iinportaut, what? to do about a nation with uiiuccepta* bly high number of unemployed who! won’t do the country’s work, hut im-* ports or tolerates an arm y of illegal! servants to harvest its fruit and ve*| get ables and to serve its tables? 
This is not merely a problem of h ir in g a new c la s s of m a n u a l laborers, wailers, dishwashers, etc J to do the menial dog work of life in 
America, but even the m edical pro­ fession is relying on im m igrants to serve the hospitals of our great cities, and take jobs in the little com m u n­ ities of the nation that c a n ’t find 
A m erican doctors and interns who will stick to Hie lonely hut valiant service of village life. 
Can’t control 
Maybe we ca n ’t control the flow of illegal im m ig ra n ts into the United 
Stales. In fiscal 1975 alone, m ore than seven million nonimmigrant visitors cam e to the United States, and in a vast country it is almost impossible, to find many of them who com e as visitors but rem a in and are given jobs by employers who evade the law for convenience, or don’t know what! the law is.

Just a man trying to do his job 

The average American Joe md Jane have some hard-set 
'efinitions of pornography and 
Heliography dealers. 
Pornography is perverse exual sm ut. 
D ealers, of 
•nurse, are deviants who get their thrills by enticing the young and weak into sin. 
P o r n o dealers, quite frankly, have their n u n way of looking ut the si­ tuation: ‘i f they don't want to see it. they don't have to walk in the door." says Matt Mattingly, the m a n a g e r of an adult bookst ore and peep show a r c a d e on E a s t H ouston S tr e e t in downtown San Antonio. 
That sign out there — " I f seeing parts of the nude body offends you, do not e n t e r " — is f a i r w a r n i n g , he contends. 
What’s more, says the 26-year-old 
Vietnam veteran, the racy, sex films, magazines and devices lie sells are good for society. 

Safety valve 

He says his stock serves as a safety valve. 

 i f a mail can get his k ic k s by fantasizing over something like this. he's less likely to go out and attack somebody," Mattingly explains. 

This U'orld has so m any pressures, t here has to be a fantasy world.

M a t t i n g l y f r o m b e h in d th e g l a s s counter of his shop where he inter- mittenlv interrupts the conversation to h e lp his s t e a d y s t r e a m of customers.

" T h e re s a much higher incidence of sex crim es in countries where this stuff is not a v a i l a b l e , " M a ttin g ly c o n tin ue s, w a lk in g buck fr om the- cash register. 

He pulls out another cigarette from his gold case. The overweight m an with disheveled reddish hair and black frame glasses chain smokes. 

Own ideas 

" L e t ’s face it. We all have our own ideas — our own little red wagons about sex." 

Mattingly doesn't a g re e with the 
Joe and Ja n e who say the material in his shop is sick and perverted

By that Mattingly says he m eans a selection of heterosexual m a terials .

Bondage and domination? Are you talking about sexual sadism ? No. he says. that stuff g a th e r s dust. M a t­ tingly says people just like the s y m ­ bolic type things on bondage and do- initiation P ure fantasy. 

Fantasy 

"That s what we sell here — fan­ tasy," says Mattingly, emphasizing his statement with a d ra m a tic m i d ­ air wave of his hand. 

" T h i s w o rld h a s so m a n y p r e s ­ s u r e s 
There h a s to be a f a n t a s y world People need a fantasy world where life can be the way they want it to be. 

"Now me. I read this," says Mat­ tingly putting down a cigarette and picking up a scien ce fiction book. 
"This is my escape." 

Science fiction is the keystone of 
Mattingly's fantasy world — the lur­ id. glossy sex magazines around him 

 are as everyday as a cup of coffee. He com par es his job as a porno dealer to that of a grocery clerk. "I .hist put the stuff on the shelves.” 
View 

T h e re a r e n ’t m a n y people w h o ’d s h a r e t h a t view w ith h i m . Y o u r a v e r a g e J o e a n d J a n e s e e p o rn o shops not only as gathering (daces for d e v ia n t s , but also as places with un­ derworld connections. 
Mattingly doesn't a g r e e with either charge. 
He claims the porno trade used to be run by organized crim e and would be run by the underworld again if it were locked out of the open market. 
"T h ese books we sell for $4 now — they’d be sold for $1(1 or $15 if they were outlawed . . . any tim e you make a n y t h i n g il le gal, o r g a n i z e d c r i m e comes iii." 
F u r t h e r more, says Mat tin cly. he allows no meetings, no loitering and no sexual activity i ii his store, " l f I catch anyone (in any kind of sexual a c tiv ity ), I throw th e m out of the shop. and they're not allowed back ." 
“ All we're trying to do here is pro­ vide something people very obviously w an t." Mattingly continues sounding like someone tired of being harassed. 
"T he only thing I’m interested i ii is making my weekly paycheck without every body in th e world telling me what to do.”

Coffee prices worldwide in steep increase 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
Coffee price s have d ou­ bled or m o r e in m a n y co un tries d u ri n g the past year, and despite dropping c o n s u m p t i o n in some* areas, a lop coffee expert says prices should continue r i s i n g for the next two years. 
"C o ffe e q u o ta t io n s a re r e g u l a t e d by the law of supply and demand. ’ said 
(ii I berm Arango Loudoun, president of the Colombian 
Coffee E x p o rte r s Associa­ tion "Hight now the supply is scarce ” 
Iii C o lo m b ia , now the world s largest pro ducer, the p ric e for a pound of coffee has doubled to $1 iii the past six months. In the 
Crated States it has lumped from $1 25 to more than $3 a pound over the past year. 
Disasters 
Coffee producers say the supply has been reduced by disasters in col fee-growing countries — including frost in Brazil, civil war in An­ gola. an e a r t h q u a k e in 
G u a t e m a l a , flo o d s in 
Colombia and Mexico and a drought in the Ivory Coast in western Africa. 
Brazil w a s the w o r l d ' s largest entice producer un­ til a frost in July 1875 des­ troy ed 7(1 per c e n t of its c ro p of n e a r l y 3 billion pounds, or about 4(1 per cent of the normal world supply for one year. 
The price in Brazil has gone from HI cents a pound lo $1 HH. and I rom $1 14 to 
$2.61 for eight ounces ot in­ stant c o ff e e 
In M exico, which produced 323 million pounds last year. the cost to the housewife rose from 75 cents to $2 iii the p a s t two years. 
Hitting respires 

Some producers are dip­ ping into their reserves to meet the world demand of some 6.36 billion pounds a year. 
A private col lee a ss o cia ­ tion in Bio de Janeiro said 
Brazil s annual coffee con­ sumption was down to 762 million pounds I rom 1.o3 

 billion pounds a few years ago. 
A m a j o r d i s t r i b u t o r in 
A rg e n ti n a , w h e r e p r i c e s are up to $4.54 from $1.81 a pound, said “ We are losing lots of money because of the decline in consumption "

Association found that peo- 

 j»Ie iii the N e t h e r l a n d s changed their coffee habits as the priee rose from $2 12 to $5 34 ,i pound L e ss than a third ol those surveyed said they ha d m a d e no change, while ll per cent s a i d they w e r e d r i n k i n g le ss col lee. 27 per cent said they were making it weaker and Jo per cent said they w e re b u y in g a c h e a p e r brand. 
Few heed calls 

But few c o u n t r i e s a r e heeding calls lirst made in the t inted Stales for an or­ ganized boycott to drive the price of col lee down 
In Israel, where the price ol a seven-ounce jar of in­ stant is up 38 lier cent to 
$3.63. the israeli Consumer 
Authority is campaigniong for a sw itch to tea

Coffee drinking halt Ii as faults 

Bv DAVID MCLEMORE 
{J N ttS S NEW S M ID '' A l WRITER 

Oh boy, coffee drinkers, you thought you had it made. 
Overzealous South American coffee producers w er­ e n ’t going to nearly double the price of coffee and get away with it. You’d fight back with a boycott, you said. 
But you forgot the single most valuable lesson of the 
21) Century: you c a n ’t win 
For example, heavy coffee drinkers in San Antonio and elsewhere might contemplate the warnings of a 
New Haven. Conn . psychiatrist before turning in their 
CUjis. 
Dr. Julien Lieb, chief of psychiatry at the Yale-New 
Haven Hospital, warned a sudden halt iii caffeine intake might cause some caffeine fiends to suffer withdrawal symptoms 
The sym pto m s include headaches, irritability, leth­ argy and constipation, he added. Non-coffee drinkers with th ese s y m p t o m s need not fear. They a r e n ’t addicted to caffeine. 
Medical r e s e a r c h e r s at the University of Texas 
Health Science Cepter here a r e n ’t as convinced as Dr. 
Lcib that a threat of coldturkey withdrawal is that eminent. 
One UT researcher, a nutritionist, said she assum ed a heavy coffee drinker who stopped suddenly would have some effects of withdrawal 
“ But we c a n ’t really say to what d e g re e ," she said 
"U rn just not a w are of any su bsta ntia l scientific research on the subject," 
T h e UT r e s e a r c h e r su g g e s te d a coffee d r i n k e r concerned about facing life cold turkey could switch to other food products containing caffeine, such as tea, cola or chocolate to reduce the effect of withdrawal. 
Yes, but then the caffeine freak unable to break the habit wuuld then have to worry about all those calories in a pot of chocolate. 
As was said earlier, you c a n ’t win.

Murdoch takes over magazines 

NEW YORK TIMES SERVICE 
NEW YORK — Rupert 
Murdoch gained full con­ trol of the New York Ma­ gazine Com pany F rid a y after reaching an out-of- court settlement with (’lay 
S. Felker, president of the company. 
The settlem en t, under which Felker will resign as president and editor of the m a g az in e, w as reach ed after a hectic and often d ram atic series of m eet­ ings between various com­ binations of the principals and their lawyers. 
They worked through the night and until late Friday afternoon, when the agree­ ment was signed. 
The urgency to reach an agreement before a court hearing — scheduled for noon 
F rid a y and r e s ­ cheduled twice during the day — on Felker’s efforts to block Murdoch’s takeover, was matched only by the urgency of some of the m a­ gazines’ executives to see if they could put out next week’s issue of New York. 
Walkout 
On T h u rs d a y the stall had walked out to show its support for Felker and its opposition to Murdoch The work stoppage was timed to prevent publication of the issue, dated -Ian 17, w hich comes out Monday. 
Hut Murdoch and several other d irectors went p e r­ sonally to the magazine of­ fices at 755 Second Ave. late 
Thursday night and put out the magazine themselves. 
F e lk e r had m a d e the same attempt earlier in the day, but indicated that it could not be done. 
However, M urdoch and 

 the other directors pasted proofs — at one point Mur­ doch discovered th»> movie listings were for the wrong week and corrected them him self — and p re p a re d copy to go to the typeset­ ters. 
Their deadline was 6:3o a m. and they finished at 
6:2o — in time to catch the airplane Ut get everything to the printer in Buffalo on time. 
Agreement 
Meanwhile, the lawyers were working in their of­ fices and at times iii Mur­ doch’s Fifth Avenue apart­ ment to get the agreement drawn up. 
Under the agreement, IO co n trib u tin g ed ito rs will stay. 
It was not immediately clear who they were. 
Howard Squadron, M ur­ doch'a lawyer, said it was the intention of Murdoch to preserve the editorial inte­ grity of the publications of the com p an y , w hich a re 
New York, New West and the Village Voice. 
He said the m a n a g in g editors of the three publi­ cations would be offered two-year contracts and gi­ ven editorial control of tin' publications. 
Staff employes who wish to stay on will also be per­ mitted to do so. Squadron said 

M urdoch p u b lish es newspapers and magazines in Australia, Great Britain and the United States. 
His other American hold­ ings include the Post, New 
York City’s only afternoon daily newspaper, the week­ ly National S tar, several

COMPILED TROM WIRE SERVICES 
MOSCOW — The Soviet army newspaper Red Star

It said Ford must “ know well the truth, which is that the Soviet Union spends every year less and h*ss of its resources on defense while U.S. military expen­ diture grow (increasingly year by year.”

A greem ent averts oil w orkers’ strike 

DENVER (AP; — A union representing 6o,oo4) oil in­ dustry employes reached agreement with Gull (iii Corp un a two-year contract Friday. The union’s president called off a threatened nationwide strike at midnight when con­ tracts with (Ether finns expired. 
A F. Grospiron, president of the Oil, Chemical and 
Atomic Workers International union, said he planned to use the Gulf agreement as a pattern in settling contracts with nearly HO other companies 
“ I do not intend to call a national strike on tJu* remain­ ing companies tonight,” he said, adding that negotiations with those other firms would continue. 
The agreement with Gulf provides a 9 per cent wage increase in the first year and an acryss-the-board 75 cents-perhour hike the second year. 
The av erag e union w o rk er e a rn ed $7.4U under the prev ious contract.

He was found slumped in the driver’s seat of the ear parked on Quixote Walk in the San Juan Homes pro­ ject shortly after ll p.m., police reported. 
Pedraza was pronounced dead at Green Hospital at 
12:o5 a.rn. of a gunshot wound to the temple. 
Officers said the driver’s door was half open.

Saturday.
