A New Year with sentimental flavor 

 b o rate , g o ld -em b ro id e re d c h a rro hats, donkey-shaped pinatas and re­ p ro d u c tio n s of p re h is to ric A ztec idols: 
The shoeshine boys and the sellers of velvet paintings are still on the plaza — and the Obispado (Bishop’s 
Palace) still stands in all its ancient majesty. 
The colonial flavor that has always m ade M onterrey such a wonderful place still lives. 
Because we were pressed for time, 
Bonnie and I had to forego one of our cherished p le a su re s — driv in g to 
Monterrey. This time we flew — 5o minutes from San Antonio by Mexi- cana. 
And Mexico started the moment we stepped into that ticket line at the San 
Antonio airport. 
On the way down there was a break in the clouds and we got a fine view' of the Rio G rande. Falcon Lake was below us and we thought we saw' the street pattern of one of our favorite towns — old Sap Ysidro that lies on the'river at the point the lake begins. 
Favorite drive 
We rented a car and early on New 
Year’s Day we headed out on one of our favorite drives in all Mexico — on the old 
Pan 
American 
Highway through those little towns south of 
Monterrey. It is now Highway H5. 
Monterrey has grown a great deal to the south. There are new subdi­ visions and hundreds of houses. But in time we had left the city. 
Then we w ere in that beautiful valley. Many of you who have driven down that valley — possibly on your way to Horsetail Falls — know how pretty it is. 
The mountains are spectacular. To our left was the high, wooded ridge that runs south from the Saddleback 

THIS m ule-pow ered “ m oU enda” (mill) south of M onterrey is one of at least 2o on the old Pan Am erican H igh w ay. But su gar cane crushing is only part of its operation. 
In-the-shuck green corn and squash are boiled in beehive ovens for sale. 

 area. And off to the west w ere the rugged Sierra Madres. 
With the gray clouds around the broken peaks, the scene was that of an old. classic German painting of m o u n ta in s. O ccasio n ally the sun would break through a narrow open­ ing and make ail eerie picture of a bare, rocky bluff 
Valley floor beauty 

But the most moving beauty was around us on the \ alley floor. Before long, the lake was on our left. The water was low and on both sides of the lakes for miles the ducks were feeding. 
Most were our favorites, the little black coots. But often we spotted the 
•w hite of canvasbacks. 
But most beautiful of all were the orange groves. Not much picking had 
Age gives flavor to Monterrey w 

Much of Monterrey’s wonderful flavor comes front being an old. old town. 

Most histories say it was founded in 159S by Don Diego de Monteniayor who had a religious motive when he named it the “ Metropolitan ( tty of 
Our Lady of Monterrey." 

Others say he was polishing apples with 
Monterrey after the viceroy of New Spain, 
Acevedo — who was the Count of Monterrey. 

 a superior and named it 
Don Gaspar de Zuniga y 

But other histories say it is even older — that Spanish soldiers and priests founded it in ISM and named it “ Santa Lucia.” 

But all agree before the Spaniards came it was a much used gathering place for Indians. Saddleback Mountain was a landmark that made the chosen gathering place certain. 

 been done and m an y tre e s w ere loaded with fully ripe oranges — gol­ den balls against the green leaves. 
But the wonder of the day were the roadside stands all along the way. 
At how many places in the world would you fiiui old-fashioned sorgh­ um mills inst outside a metropolitan city of more than a million? th e re were a half-dozen or more of the "m o lie n d a s ” beside the road. 
These are the sorghum mills of Fast 
Texas and tin* Deep South of 5o or more years ago. 
Old-type press 
While these mills were using sugar cane and not the old-time sorghum cane, the press was the old type. 
The su g a r cane is fed en d -first through two upright revolving metal drums to squeeze the juice from it 
Atop the press is a big wooden pole. 
The short butt-end of tin* pole is on one side of the press for balance and the a n im a l that fu rn is h e d the 
“ horse-power" is hitched to the long, tapering end. A rope angles off from the bridle to the pole, forcing the animal to walk around and around in a circle. Much shouting keeps the animal moving. 
We saw a horse — a mule — and a burro — at three successive mo­ liendas. 
Long stalks ol sugar cane for the mills were piled on the ground or stacked against a tree or stand 
Cooking fires were going at e\ery stand. A wood fire was blazing under washtubs filled with green corn in the shuck — ste a m ris in g in w hite clouds, 
Files of corn still to be boiled and sh u ck s from that alre a d y cooked were beside the tubs. 
This boiled corn — “ d o te s " —is sold on many street corners in Mon­ terrey and in most Mexican towns. 
Hot from a little cart and brushed 

 with a red pepper sauce, it is a po­ pular dish. 
Several stands were cooking meat 
— pork, cabrito and even rabbit — over glowing coals iii big grills. 
But most unusual of all were the piles of big squash. Each squash was put in a little strin g h arn ess like those sometimes found around hang­ ing flower pots It had a loop on it so the squash could be dipped in a big beehive pot of boiling water and sn gar cane juice 
Wheti tile boiling was finished — and the squash now sweet and the color of caramel — it was hung from a long horizontal pole in front of the stand. The siring harness was used to hang it. 

The colonial flavor that has alw ays m ade Mon­ terrey such a wonderful place still lives 

Tamales steaming in big cans wert' so full of flavor. 
And for sale on tables were little b o t t l e s of pepper sauce m ade with tiny, round p ep p e rs. B esides the sauce bottles were jars of hone> and browu-sugar “ pilones" (loaf sugar) 
Wonderful world 
Most ol the stands had sacks of oranges — standing i i i clusters of sacks or hanging from the roof sup­ ports of the stand. And at some stands and at many other places beside the road were great piles of golden oranges — a truck load — spilled out on the ground. Besides these mounds were piles of tanger­ ines. their reddish hue contrasting with the gold of the oranges 
What a lively and wonderful world

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday January 8 1977 
Page 
I -B 

Both tim e and place made this a sentimental journey. 
The time was New Year’^ — year's end and year's b egin­ ning. 
Tile place was Monterrey, a town as timeless as Cerro de Silla — 
Saddleback Mountain — that is its symbol. 
Each December Bonnie and I try to find a place that has special ties with the changing of the year that is at hand. 
Last year we spent New Y ear’s Eve night in our cam per on Padre Island. 
W;e were drawn there by the know­ ledge the sam e surf that was rolling in when 1775 became 1776 was rolling in when 1975 becam e 1976. At. m id­ night we arose and, standing at the w a te r’s edge, saluted the n a tio n ’s 
2ooth Birthday with sparklers and a tiny Roman candle — our “ rocket’s t, red glare.” 
Turning to Mexico 
I 
As New Y e a r’s ap p ro ach ed this year, our m inds kept turning to a troubled Mexico — and all the won­ derful visits we have had there over the years. 

We particularly thought of Monter­ rey. 
As do so m any San A n to n ia n s, 
Bonnie and I have a special affection for Monterrey. We have been going there together for 3o years. Bonnie has been \isiting Monterrey since she was a little girl. 
This year we decided we wanted the stroke of midnight on New' Y ear’s 
Eve to find us standing in the plaza in front of the Monterrey Cathedral — and looking up to m oonlit Saddle­ back. 
We were in that wonderful old pla­ za half an hour before midnight. F a­ milies were scurrying by us to enter the crowded church for the first m ass of the New Year. 
Fog, clouds, drizzle 

G O U RM ET fare — M e xican style — is prepared by this roadside chef by dipping ca­ labaza (squash) in string har­ ness into pot of boiling w ater in beehive-shaped oven 

Alas! When midnight came, the fog and the clouds and the little drizzle kept us from seeing Saddleback. But that didn’t m atter much for we knew that Saddleback — our Magic Moun­ tain — was there. 
On the surface Old M onterrey — with more than 4oo years of history behind it — has changed much in the last 3o years. 
In our lib ra ry th ere is an en c y ­ clopedia that gives Monterrey’s 1946 population. Monterrey proper is esti­ mated as having a population at that time of 19o.ooo 
The 1977 W'orld A lm anac gives 
Monterrey’s metropolitan population as 1.543,399. 
Monterrey now is a great industrial and com mercial city. It is a city of steel m ills and brew eries — glass sky-scrapers — homes climbing al­ most to the top of the long mountain rid g e a c ro s s th e riv e r bed from downtown. 
Yet m an y of th e c h a n g e s a re changes on the surface only. 
The Ancira, La Luisiana and San­ born’s are still there. The curio shops are still overflowing with their ela­

Don’t smell the flowers 

M ELROSE PARK, 111. 
(AP) —- A 4-foot boa con­ strictor is loose in Am ling’s 
Flower land. 
A spokesm an said the snake has been m issing from its g lass enclosure since W ednesday. It may have left the sto re’s pet departm ent and slithered into the big display area of flowers and plants, he said. 

“ The sn a k e se lls for 
$69.99 and can go four m onths w ithout e a tin g .” the spokesm an said. “ It really can’t hurt anyone, but it sure could scare so­ m eone b en d in g over to smell a flower.”

San Antonio EXPRESS-N FW S—•—Saturday January 8 1 9 7 7 

Country music twangs way to River Walk 

JOHNNY BUSH 
. . . country on Paseo 

SWT exhibit 
SPfcClAl TO THI EXPSESS-Nf-WS 
SAN MART OS - South­ west Texas State Universi­ ty's annual art faculty exb- hibit opens Jan. 19 and runs through- Feb. 2 in the Art 
Building Gallery. 
Hours are 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. weekdays. 

The Paseo del Rio's an­ nual Great Country River 
Festival is scheduled for 
Feb 4-6. 

The announcement was made by Frank Phelps, president of the Paseo del 
Rio Association, which sponsors the event in con­ junction with KKYX Radio. 

During the three-day sa­ lute to country-western m usic, continuous live entertainment is planned for three staging areas along the downtown River 
Walk between the Crockett 
Street bridge and the 
Arneson River Theater. 

Among the entertainers from Nashville performing during the festival will be 
Je rry Max Lane, Claude 
Gray, Jack ie Ward and 

Nick Nixon, aceordiri; to f?*Vi R / r n i h i l it ire 
Paul Morgan, program 1X 1o director for KKYX Ra$o. 

Popular area enter­ tainers, including Moe 
Bandy, Darrell McCall and 
Johnny Bush, will alsrt per­ form on the Arneson stage. 

Local bands will enter­ tain aboard river barges 

 during the festival. 

Hours for the event are from 5 p.m. to ll p m. on 
Feb. 4, noon to ll p m. on 
Feb 5 and noon to IO p m on Feb. 6. 
The Great Country River 
Festival is free 

A R iver W alk perfor­ mance by the international singing and dancing troupe, Up With People, will be presented Friday evening. 

Staged at the footbridge near the Kangaroo Court, the 8o-member cast w ill perform on the river banks 

 and aboard barges. 

Tile cast holds students from eight countries and more than 4o states 

The free half-hour per­ formance will begin at 6 pm. 
V 
Paseo del Rio Association members. Rick Grinnan. of 

 the Royal Street Crossing, and Franklin Hicks, of Casa 
Rio Mexican Restaurant, will attend Food Service '77 in Amsterdam next week. 
The only representatives from Texas, the pair will join 75 other U.S. represen­ tatives at the international food show . 
Billed as the largest food 

 show in the world, dele­ gates will study the latest in food equipment and pre­ paration. 
The River Walk restaur­ ant managers will also at­ tend another part of the conference in 
London, which will consist of a se­ m inar on the free enterprise system.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS—-Saturday January 8 1977 
Candidates like 1o-1 

By JAMES MCCRORY 
The 1o-1 city dis­ tricting plan F riday served as a showcase for three-and-a-half candidates for mayor in the April city elec­ tion. 
Three announced candi­ dates for mayor — Mayor 
Lila Cockrell, John Mon- frey and Dr. J o s e San 
Martin — can’t agree on who should be mayor. But they are in agreement the d is tric tin g plan is one whose time has come. 
John Steen, who is half­ way in the m a y o r’s race, joined the o th e r th ree through a w ritte n s t a t e ­ ment at a press conference at which ail four expressed support for the IO I plan 
On passage 
His e n try in the race, 
Steen sa id , d ep en d s w h eth er the 
1o-1 plan passes. If it does, he enters, and it it doesn't, tie doesn’t on ground there’ll be no ci­ ty election because the U.S. 
J u s tic e D ep a rtm e n t will block it. 
Monfrey. who lost to Mrs. 
Cockrell in a runoff in the 
1o75 m ayor's race, contest­ ed w h eth e r the m a y o r ’s race would not be rv.: re­ gardless of the outcome of the Jan. 15 city* districting election. 

The new districting plan is one whose tim e has com e, candidates f o r m ayor agree 

He noted the City Charter had been amended to pro­ vide the m a y o r will be elected at large. And the 
IO-1 plan provides the same thing as far as the mayor is concerned The proposed charter change, he notes, would have IO council dis­ tricts, but makes no change in the mayoral candidates’ situation 
No answer 
Monfrey said he had tried to Check his theory out on a n u m b e r of law y ers, but none has come up with a concrete answer to his hy­ pothesis. 
AH three announced can­ didates agreed turnout is the key to victory or defeat at the polls for the 1o-1 plan. 
Monfrey said his latest poll reflects the plan will carry by a 2-1 margin. But he cautioned that is down from a 3-1 m argin only a couple of months ago. 
Mrs. Cockrell and San 
Martin see the election a lot closer than that. 
M rs Cockrell said she sees the election m uch closer than the 2-1 prnjec-

 lion reflected by Monfrey’s poll. 
She noted opponents of the plan will be spending a lot of money in the closing days of the campaign, and sin1 predicted people will be m a k in g up th e ir m in d s right up to Jan. 15. 
No money 
The mayor, in a side-shot at 
M onfrey, noted she hasn’t had the money to put into “ e x p en siv e polls ” 
M onfrey had the polls commissioned, the first one before he entered the race. 
San Martin agreed with 
Mrs. Cockrell that the elec­ tion is close. 
A fo rm e r co u n c ilm an and m ayor pro te m . San 
Martin hazarded a guess the spread was 6-5 in favor of districting. He explained he isn’t being pessimistic, only realistic. 
“ Bad w eather (on elec­ tion day) and a low turnout will m ean an y th in g can h a p p e n ,” the doctor o b ­ served. 
M rs. Cockrell show ed both sides of the districting coin. 
One of the advantages of the present at large system of elec tin g council m e m b e rs, she sa id , is voters can hold all the council members accounta­ ble for their actions and votes, and it inclines coun­ cil members to view issues as a whole. 
Same area 
But over-riding liabilities to the at large system. Mrs. 
Cockrell said is the fact that under the present sys­ tem m ost of the council m e m b ers com e from “ a 

 particular geographical a r­ ea.” 
An at large system, she said, would take into a c ­ count the m u lti-cu ltu re d background of the city and the neighborhoods and give balanced representation on the council. 
A second benefit of the district plan, she said, is it gives a person w ith o u t large financial hacking a chance to run and win by perso n al co n tac t w ith a smaller constituency. 
Misnomer 
“ T he 
IO-1 plan is a m isnom er,” Monfrey said in support of his argum ent there’ll be a m ayor’s race regardless of the outcome of the Jan. 15 election. 
Monfrey pointed out he favored districting when a districting plan was voted down several years ago. He noted the plan which was voted down was different from the plan being p r e ­ sented voters Jan. 15, and the original districting plan was prepared in large by people opposed to the pre­ sent plan. 
He favors the districting plan, Monfrey said, b a s i­ cally b ec au se it m a k e s 

' I Ii i n gs a re eh a a g in g a n d we must change with the times.' 

 council m em bers more re­ sponsive to the needs of the people who put them in of­ fice. 
Monfrey also cautioned voters not to he misled by c rie s of “ b o s s is m ” and 
“ w ardism ” should council mem bers he elected by district, Mrs. Cockrell and 
San Martin concurred. 
Noting he was active in politics 46 years ago when the voters switched from the m ayor-com m issioners 

 form of government to the council-m anager sy stem . 
San Martin said ‘‘the City 
Charter is not set in con­ c r e te .” San M artin c a m ­ p aigned for council- manager government. 
“ We have to m odify it 
(the charter) from tim e to time to meet the needs of the d ay ,” San M artin ob­ served. 
“ T h in g s a re c h a n g in g and we m ust change with the tim es.” 
San M a rtin , o b se rv in g the Justice Department “ is as stubborn as a m u le .” said he believes the city should have sued the J u s ­ tice D e p a rtm e n t when it originally interferred with the local election process. 
B ut, he sa id , the city should adopt the districting plan, regardless of the J u s ­ tice D epartm ent interven­ tion in recent annexations questioned by the Justice 
Department. 
Diluted 
The Justice Departm ent charged city annexations in 
1o72 d ilu ted the v o tin g strength of Mexican-Amer- icans and th re a te n e d to block the next election until the m atter was corrected. 
But the d ep a rtm en t in d i­ cated ad o ption of a d i s ­ tricting plan would satisfy it. 
As for misconceptions on the authority of the council members, San Martin said he learned a councilm an 
“ c a n ’t even get a traffic light put in. 
“ Political p atro n ag e Is the key of w a rd is m and b o s s is m ,” 
San 
M a rtin a v e rre d , “ and you d o n ’t have it as long as you have rounvil-manager govern- m ent.” 
T he m a y o r e x p re sse d confidence “ a lot of big money thrown in to defeat it” will not beat the d is ­ tricting plan Jan. 15.

Professor: 
1o-1 more democratic 

By DAVID HENDRICKS 
Districting for City Coun­ cil would put ail end to the city’s past monolithic go­ vernment and better repre- sent San Antonio’s p lu ra­ listic neighborhoods. 
That was the message for about 4o E ast Side r e s i­ dents during a briefing on the 1o-district council plan to be before city votes Jan. 
15. 
Dr 
Bill Crane, political science professor at St. 
M ary ’s U niversity, said neighborhood politics could re tu rn with the s in g le ­ member districts.

“ There was a time when you could put a silver dollar on a m ap of San Antonio and cover where a quorum

Cold mass aims ai state 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
Tartly cloudy skies and mild tem peratures gave Texans another break in winter weather Friday but weathermen warned that a mass of irctie air was poised to roll into 
Northwest Texas Saturday morning. 
The National Weather Service said a strong arctic cold front was already in the Rockies Friday morning and moving toward Texas. 
Temperatures were expected to drop drastically in the 
Panhandle and the South Plains Saturday, the service said. 
Thermometers across the state Friday were mainly in the 5os and 6os with Brownsville reporting the late after­ noon high of 64 degrees under partly cloudy skies. 
Weathermen said the approaching cold front was ex­ pected to bring bitter weekend w eather to Northwest 
Texas. 
The forecast for the rest of the state called for mostly cloudy skies Saturday along with cooler temperatures.

 ol tho City Council lived," 
Dr. Crane .said. 
The result of districting would be lots of porkbar- relling, councilm en fight­ ing for goods and services for his district. 
This can lie called ward politics, with its bad con­ notations, Dr. Crane said, but “ p o litic s is a fig h t am ong com peting groups anyway.” 
Single-m em ber districts would also open up the chances of election to more people, Dr. Crane said. 
An a t-la rg e city -w id e ca m p a ig n would have to spend at le a st $16,ooo to have a ch a n c e , he sa id , while within a district a cam paign costing $8oo to 
$1,ooo would have a chance. 

Campaign costs 

“ Who has $16,ooo to run for an office that pays only 
$2o w e e k ? ” asked 
Dr, 
Crane

Dry type o f pleurisy is painful 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: 
My dad is 91 and has pleurisy. His doctor drained fluid from his chest cavity twice, a quart the first time and two quarts the second. He did have X-rays and a number of tests done. 
What causes the fluid to accumulate? Dad has a persistent cold, a runny nose, and phlegm. He tends to cough when he eats or drinks. He says he feels tired and wants to sleep most of the time. — CC. 

It’s anatomy lesson time. 
The lungs are covered with a double membrane. These pleural “ sheets” have a narrow space between called the pleural cavity. Normally, one rides over the other, allow­ ing for easier expansion of the _ lungs. An inflammation of this * pleural space is called pleur­ isy. 
The pleurisy can be either what is called “ wet” or “ dry.” 
In your father’s case, since you do not mention any great pain involved. I assume it is the wet type. The dry type is quite painful because of fric­ tion of the two swollen mem­ branes rubbing against each other, as they do in breathing. 
Any infection that affects the lungs can cause pleurisy. 
Pneumonia is a prime one, as is tuberculosis. Also, conges­ tive heart failure or malignancy may lead to it. as can a serious attack of in­ fluenza. 
This condition would naturally make your dad feel tired to the extent it interferes with his proper breathing. 
Bedrest and heat applications help. Antibiotics to attack the infection can be considered. 
Protective fluid is produced in any infection of mucous tissue as in the pleura. It will continue to be produced until the infection is cleared up. 
Cataracts 
Dear Dr. Thosteson: Are babies born with cataracts? Do many young people have them, and if so can you explain why? — Mrs. M L. 
Babies and young children can have cataracts. Those present at birth are called congenital cataracts, and result from a birth defect, as from rubella (German measles) early in pregnancy. Immunizing of young gi$s has prac­ tically eliminated that problem, however. 
Inflammation of the eyes during fetal growth can also cause cataracts, as can a mixup of gene combinations, causing faulty development of the eye lens. 
Later, certain metabolic disorders as galactosemia 
(inability to handle milk sugar) can result to cataract formation. It is rare. For a complete discussion of catar­ acts (and glaucoma) sent 25 cents and a stamped, self- addressed envelope to me in care of this newspaper, and 
1 11 send you my booklet on this. 
Dear Dr. Thosteson: I am a 71-year-old woman who eats between IOO and 15o radishes in about four or five days — well-cleaned and peeled. I eat them like candy and really crave them. Am I lacking something in my diet? — Mrs. 
E L . 
Too young 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: Can using the birth control pills before puberty cause any problems for a young girl? — 
Mrs. T G. 
It should not be done. 
Of course, from a practical standpoint, there would be no pregnancy risk if ovulation is not occurring. That is the principal sign of puberty. However, there may be some pre-pubertal girls using contraceptive pills “ to be sure.” 
.They shouldn't. 
To learn the moior categories of prostate trouble — symptoms, treat­ ment, how to speed recovery —- read Dr. Thosteson* booklet, "The Pesky 
Prostate ” For a copy write to him in care of this newspaper, enclosing long, self-addressed, stamped envelope and 25 cents.

MOTHERHOOD 
HISTORY 

My subject is a commercial worm raising operation in a residential area. 
What are city ordinances controlling a worm farm that covers an entire back yard? This is an unsightly eyesore and lf my common sense is correct, an operation of this size will have the smell of a pig sty 
Can such an operation be legal in an area that is zoned for homes only? 
What course of actions do I have or who must I contact to have this terminated? Can I he city government make this person remove the worm farm or must I hire an attorney to have this done? 
This particular situation is happening in my community and the front is that it is a hobby. 
Your reply will be appreciated as several neighbors are going to be waiting for the answer 
A. W. S.

Russell L i n d i e s of the 

San Antonio Building and 
Zoning Department said worm farms are a rarity and not listed as a categor­ ized use in the zoning re­ gulations. 
Hut worm farms are not 

 allowed in residential ar­ eas. Residentially zoned A areas are for single fa­ milies. B areas are for du­ plexes and home opera­ tions, such as seam­ stresses, dentists with one 

 chair or the like. 
To register a complaint, 

 contact Building and Zon­ ing at 225-1o51. Lindley said they would take action within three days. 
After Building and Zon­ ing contacts the person operating the worm farm. he will have IO days to cor­ rect the situation. lf he does not comply 

 with Building and Zoning, the ease will be taken lo 
Municipal Court. 

CB interference 

Please help me with a problem that I am facing for the coming new year. I own a 19 inch color television set that receives Citizens Band (C B ) reception from my neigh­ bor’s driveway which is relatively close to our set 
The reception from the C.B. grows weaker with dis­ tance, hut it is still irritating. 
The neighbors have cooperated with us and moved the car a distance from our set. What I was wondering, to try to completely resolve the problem, is if there is any type of electrical addition or gadget which can be used to eliminate this reception. 
Please let me know as soon as possible so we can remedy this situation. 

It. M. 

The answer to your prob­ lem is a linear filter. 
Electrotex. 
12oo 
W. 

Hildebrand Ave., 735 9271, sells the television inter­ ference (T V !) traps tor both citizens band radios and television sets. 

The citizens hand TV I 

 trap sells for about $2o to 
$25, depending on the size and type of model you will need. 

The television TVI trap 

 sells for $H to $1o.

Copyright! 

I would like to know how to get a song copyrighted. 
Also, can several songs be copyrighted at the same time? I have heard many suggestions on copyrighting songs, but nobody seems to have a complete answer. 
In addition, where or to whom can I sell my songs without getting ripped off? 

For all information on cop>righting, send for 

“ (General Information on 
Copyrights,” Register of 
Copyrights, Library of 
Congress. 
Washington, 

D C.. 29559. 
Ib is booklet has all in­ formation on copyrighting literary , dramatic, musical 

C. L. T. 

 and artistic works. You can even copyright maps and photographs. 

 lf you have an attorney, 

 vou should also check op­ tions with him. Lawyers know about cop*right laws and they may have some helpful suggestions. 

Shower control 

The other day you published a question and reply about shower control regarding the metering of waler flow in a shower. 
I agree, there is no device lo meter the water, but there is a simple device which limits or controls the flow of water 
The preset flow rate is independent of waler pressure, within normal limits, aud rates of flow art* available from two to lh gallons per minute for domestic use; through hundreds of gallons per minute for commercial or industrial applications. 
There are several manufacturers of this device, and it is inexpensive. about 15. 

The device is a shaped, calibrated rubber orifice which expands and contracts uniformly in size as water pressure decreases or increases, so that the rate of flow is constant. 
I agree thai it would be Impractical and fairly expensive in the usual residence lo meter the water used in a single shower. 
However, like most things, it could In* done if expense is no objection. 
S. M. 

Thank you very much for 

 this additional Information. 
The B It (i flow regula­ tors are available at Frie­ drich Air Conditioning and 
Refrigeration Co. There are various sizes and capa­ cities. 
The Lions ( tub also has a 

 shower control device in its 
International Magazine. 
The device, a Noland i Shower Flow Control, cuts 

 waler consumption in half when installed in a shower head. 
The shower flow control 

 henelits the consumer and can be easily installed by the homeowner. 
Only 
Lions 
Club 

 members can sell this shower flow control. E ach shower flow control pack­ age (containing two) sells tor $1. 

San Antonio EXPRESS-N EW S— Saturday January 8 1977 
Villa shows little change in 3o years 

Continued from Page IB 

 this stretch of roadway was’ 
One of our most pleasant hours was spent nearby — and you’ve missed something if you haven’t visited these old towns off the road here. 
We chose to visit Villa de Santiago 
—- little changed since we first visited it 3o years ago. We parked on the little plaza, beside a blooming rosebush and climbed a high flight of steps to enter the old church of San­ tiago el Apostol 

The Nativity scene in front of the altar was so appealing. Dirt had been brought in and placed across the raised floor iii front of the altar. It was a Holy Land desert scone in miniature. 

In the d irt many sm all desert plants had been placed. Some of the larger plants were draped with 
Spanish moss. 

Amid the plants were many small figures. Some were Bib lical ch ar­ acters 
— the 
W ise 
Men. the 
Shepherds. . . But many were simply people working in the fields and dressed in the fashion of long ago 
Mexico. 

II hat loving care had gone into making this 
Christmas scene 

A sm all, shiny silver a rtific ia l 
C hristmas tree seemed touchingly appropriate. But most appealing of all was the big maguey plant — its flaring green leaves decorated with bright gold, blue and red balls. 

What loving care had gone into making this Christmas scene! 

But moments that live forever in memory come at unexpected times and places. 

Though there were many cele­ brants in other parts of tile hotel, the 
“ 19oo Bar” at the Ancira was a quiet place after midnight when Bonnie and I dropped in from welcoming 
1977 on the nearby plaza. 

The bar itself is m assive and beautiful. It bas all the dignity of the turn of the century that gives the room its name. 
There were only about 15 or 2o people in the room when we sat down in one of the equally massive dark wood and red leather booths. Nearly 
Labor group endorses 2 

The San Antonio AFL-CIO's Com­ mittee on Political Education has endorsed two candidates for the San 
Antonio River Authority and the Ed ­ wards Underground Water District iii the Jan. 15 election 
Endorsed by COPE for re-election to his Place 2 hoard post with the 

 river authority was William Hay man 

Bunny bulkin was endorsed by 
COPE for a post on the underground water district board 
COPE earlier had approved the 1o-1 city districting plan and urged labor members to support it. 

 all those there were men and plainly were regulars — no tourists. 
The door to the street opened and in walked a tall, thin, bald man wearing a long overcoat. 
Greeted by applause 

He was greeted as “ Maestro” and there was a sprinkling of applause. 
Without taking off his overcoat or saying a word, the man sat down at the piano on a little platform at one 
('lid of the bar. He adjusted the dis­ tance of the piano bench and sounded some wonderful, deep-toned chords. 
Then he played “ Happy Birthday” and followed it by “ Las Manunitas.” 
As he finished, those present clapped — not boisterously but in the kindest way. 
The man rose from the piano bench, made a one-quarter turn to face his listeners and bowed as for­ m ally as a concert pianist at 
Carnegie Hall. A slight but pleased sm ile flicked across his angular, high-cheek-boned face. 
Then it dawned on Bonnie and me that the pianist was one of Los Ino- centes — The Innocent Ones — and those in the bar were treating him with wonderful kindliness. 
Next he played the Wedding March 
I in a fashion that would honor any bride. 
Hows, little smile 
Again the applause — again the bows aud the little smile. 
We stayed for four or five pieces — most of them the old classics of 
Mexico. After each came the ap­ plause and the bows. 
We don't know who moved us most 
— the gentle man at the piano or the kind hearts who honored him by their reception of his playing. 

Parking lot doesn’t hurt 
Alamo site 

E V E N THE. steam is tem pting when fresh-pulled green corn is boiled in its shuck in an open-air pot at a roadside stand near Monterrey 

By WILSON MCKINNEY 

Building a small staff parking lot on the Alamo grounds did no damage to the historic site, state ar­ cheologist Curtis Tunned said Friday. 
Tunned said the parking lot, being built just inside tha east wad of the Alamo grounds, was examined 
Friday by Dr. Tom Hester of the University of Texas at San Antonio at the re­ quest of the State Historical 
Commission. 
Dr. Hester reported the lot was on a portion of the grounds which had been filled in during the late 
193os. Leveling of the sur­ face for the lot did not go through the 193o fill, Tun­ nel! said Hester reported. 
“ In this case no damage was done,” Tunned said. , 
The Alam o was trans-

CHOOSE FROM c J £ 
★ CHOCTAW it STUART 
A r MOHAWK ★ SUCCESS ★ CHEROKEE' s i r 93 

W ASHINGTON (A P ) - 
Thomas B. Lance, named budget director by .Jimmy 
Curter, was investigated last year for possible elee- tion-luw violations in 
Lance’s 1974 campaign for governor of Georgia. But sources say the Ju s tic e 
Department decided there were no grounds for pro­ secution. 
Tile case (‘entered on campoign-furid overdrafts honored by Lance’s bank in 
Calhoun. Ga. The acting com ptroller of the cu r­ rency, who regulates na­ tional banks, says the over­ drafts were repaid at the end of the months in which they occurred. 
The Justice Department sources said prosecutors concluded that only tech­ nical irregularities were involved. 
Told Carter 

Lance, reached by tele­ phone in Atlanta, said. 
“ They investigated as they should aud reached the conclusion that there was nothing to it.’’ He said he had told Carter about the matter and that Carter had not expressed any concern. 
“ I told him so he’d know,” 
Lance said 
Lance said lie wrote a 
$5,o9o check and a letter of intent to the bank before starting his gubernatorial campaign to insure that 
‘‘any possible expenses would be charged to me in order that there wouldn’t be any question about it." 
President-elect Carter’s press secretary, 
Judy 
Powell, said: “ Obviously, we knew about this prior to the tune he (Lance) was named to OMB (Office of 
Management and Budget), and from what I ’ve been able to determine it ap­ pears that ... (he) actually went above and beyond what is usually done to in­ sure that any cam paign expenses that occurred were billed to him rather than to the bank." 
Powell said it is not unu­ sual for a bank to honor campaign overdrafts. He said such debts sometimes are carried longer than 
• until the end of the month.” 
The investigation began after a routine audit at the 
Calhoun F irst National 
Bank. Lance headed the bank when he ran to suc­ ceed Carter as governor of 
Georgia. He was defeated in the Democratic prunary by George Bushet*, the pre­ sent governor. 
Hubert Bloom, acting com ptroller of the cu r­ rency, said the bunk ex­ aminer who conducted the audit found that the Lance for Governor Campaign 
Committee had set up an account in Lance s bank and used it to pay cam ­ paign expenses. On several occasions, Bloom said, the account was overdrawn, and the bank honored the overdrafts. 
He said the bank ex­ aminer questioned whether the practice of honoring campaign-fund overdrafts. 

 constituted improper cor­ porate campaign contribu­ tions. 

Gov. J.J . Exon of Nebras­ ka. was closed to the press and lo the public, which in­ cluded some 
Montana ranchers who said they had been invited 
Among those attending was John W hite, Texas 
Agriculture Commissioner and a vigorous Texas cam­ paigner for Jim m y Carter. lie has been mentioned as a possible deputy agriculture secretary. 
White, 52. said he has not talked recently with 
Carter or his transition staff and said he had no in­ dication of how strongly he might be considered for the job. 
Asked if he would support 
Hie appointment of Carol 
Foreman, director of the 
Consumer Federation of 
America, who reportedly is 

 also considered for the post, W hite refused to comment on her specifical­ ly. 
‘ The departm ent does need some consum er cred ib ility,” he said. ‘‘I don’t know of any business in the world that goes out of its way to offend its cus­ tomers,” White said. “ The department has had a con­ cept of an adversary posi­ tion.” 
Bergland was expected to arrive from Plains, Ga., for a 6 p.m. dinner and evening discussion with the group. 
‘‘Our purpose is not to box in the new agriculture secretary,” Exon said in opening comments, tie de­ scribed Bergland as a 
“ good listener, even if he doesn’t agree with every­ thing we say." 

(erred to the Daughters of the Republic of Texas under a 1993 law requiring the governor’s permission before structural changes could be made to the shrine. 
The Alamo Committee of the DRT had taken the po­ sition no permission was needed for the parking lot because no digging was to take place. 
Tunnell said the work was covered by the Anti­ quities Code and did need clearance by the antiquities committee of the historical commission. 
“ I ’ve asked them (the 
DRT) to be more careful in the future about notifying us and the San Antonio 
Conservation 
S o c ie ty ," 
Tunnell said. 
“ It all turned out well, but the bad thing about this sort of thing is when it conies as a surprise,” he said. 
Public called 
Work oil the lot had pro­ gressed unnoticed until 
Thursday, when members of the public called San 
Antonio Historical Planner 
Patricia Osborne about it. 
There is no legal re ­ quirement the city be noti­ fied of work on the Alamo grounds. Mrs. Osborne re­ layed the report to the State 
Historical Commission. 
Tunnell said hundreds of sites iii the state are cov­ ered by the 
Antiquities 
Code: state parks, old forts, 
.even some county court­ houses. 
“ This sort of thing conies up for us every day,” he said. “ It doesn’t always end as well as this."

Edward Betts Monday at 
7:3o p.m. at the San Antonio 
Art lnsititute.

J. BLANTON BILK, ‘PEOPLE’ FOUNDER 
...with Peggy Balcombe-Moody, Bob Marbut at party 

By EVE LYNN SAWYER 
A preview , cocktail dinner show of Up With People in the St. 
Anthony Hotel £ave a VIP au­ dience a taste of what to ex­ pect at the public performance at 
8 p.m . Saturday, Jan. 15, in 
Laurie Auditorium. 
J. Blanton Belk of Tucson, founder and president of this international mu­ sical production and educational or­ ganization, mingled among the 125 or so guests and east members. 
Belk said he would leave Saturday for Los Angeles to attend Pele RozelLs pre-Super Bowl cocktail .carty in the 
Pasadena Civie Auditorium. 
The 8o-member cast giving the enth­ usiastic show is one of six performing all over the world in a peopie-to-people relationship. 
Up with People is non-profit. Belk told of having lunch in Mexico City with the wife of President Jose Lopez Por­ tillo and being asked to give a benefit show in the. National Auditorium Feb. ll. 
Mexico 
The east appearing in San Antonio will perform in Mexico. Jolie Cross of 
Philadelphia will lead the group south of the border. 
• 
Another cast will perform in Belfast. 

 w here they w ill be guests in homes just like in all the countries where they perform. This year they will go to IO countries and live in some 8o-1oo homes each. 
In June, one east will give a show in 
Poland, and will be presented with an international award earned after an appearance there last June. 
The casts are composed of young persons aged 18-25 from every nationa­ lity, race and financial background. 
Often they sing in the language of the country where they’re appearing. Oth­ erwise. the translation of the songs is flashed on an overhead screen. 
Jerry Shelsta, musical director from 
Casper. Wyo., travels with all six casts and helps them develop their potential as individuals as well as performers. 
He told of applications they always receive after a performance. Over 1o.ooo people a year are interviewed as poten­ tial members. They must pay tuition. 

The qualities the personnel director looks for arc personality, attitude, and orientation to people. Their singing and dancing abilities arc way down the list of prerequisites. 

The songs are written by the cast and staff members. One of the first in the preview show was the “ Song for the 
Paper Boy” w ritten with the insight of a former carrier. The show is completely

Philosophical lyrics a cast member wrote after living with un impover­ ished farm family in Yu­ goslavia include. “ You know, the rich are some-* times those with plenty, and the poor, those who only have each other.” 
Experience 

Learning, through min­ gling with people from everywhere is a major benefit of the casts of Up with People and their au­ diences. 
They visit hos­ pital patients, prison in­ mates, old people’s homes’

 residents, schools and col­ leges. 
( ast members also go to see the institutions in a town, visit with the indivi­ duals there, and share all kinds of learning exper­ iences. 
Pounder Belk is hoping that the friendships and good will arising from this interchange of ideas will eventually lead to world peace. It’s a terrific jiossi- bility. 
The upcoming appear­ ances of Up with People are sponsored by KENS C han­ nel 5. In addition to the show in Laurie Auditorium, the cast will sing in front of the 
Alamo at 
2 pm . 
Wednesday and on barges on the San Antonio River at the footbridge between 
Commerce and Crocket at ti p.m. Friday. 
This 3o-minute river ap­ pearance will be given in the Farm er’s Market in case of rain. Students at 
John F. Kennedy and Fox 
Tech high schools will also see a free show Thursday.

Tau chapter of

Northern

Country Club for a luncheon commemorating the 4oth anniversary of the chapter’s founding.

Happenings 1976-77,”

Don M. Taylor. Social ar­ rangements are being made by Mrs. o. () Key.

Sunday. Gamma Phi is the host chapter.

Tom Buel, district presi­ dent, will conduct the exe­ cutive board meeting. 
Mrs. Raymond Lueders will conduct the Past Pre­ sidents’ Auxiliary meeting.

In the third year of the reign of King Jehoiakim of Judah, Babylon's King Nebuchadnezzar attacked Jerusalem and took away many of the treasures He also decreed that certain bright, eager sunaaV ^hooI-’iOAM children of Judah should be brought to his palace for a three-year educational and training program .' w a r s h ip - 1^ a m ^ ^ 
Am ong those selected from Judah were four young men of exceptional character and intelligence: wed°EveV-7 w p m 
D aniel (who was called Belteshazzar); Hananiah (who was called Shadrach); M ishael (called Nursery Provided 
Meshach) and Azariah (called Abednego) 
"A s for these four children, God gave them knowledge and skill in all learning and wisdom: Daniel had understanding in all visions and dreams 
And in all matters of wisdom and understanding, that the king inquired of them, he found them ten times better than all the m agicians and astrologers that were in all his realm." (Daniel 1:17 & 2o)

IO West A v e 

W ASHINGTON POST SERVICE 
LONDON — A restricted bonk appar­ ently intended for local and lower-level officials has been smuggled out of the 
Soviet Union and provides an unusual glimpse of the bureaucratic web the 
Soviet Union has wrapped around the practice of religion. 
Some of the restrictions seem to be aimed at preventing the use of religion against the state or, at most, avoiding any church-state collaboration. For example: 
“ Religious associations and servants of the cults should not: 
“ A) Use prayer meetings of believers to make political speeches that contra­ dict the interests of Soviet society; 
“ B) Encourage believers to refuse to fulfill their duties as citizens; 
“ O Conduct propaganda directed at isolating believers from active partici­ pation in the state, cultural and socio­ political life of the country; 

“ D> P erfo rm religious rites and ceremonies in state, social and cooper­ ative institutions and enterprises.” 
Prisons are a specific exception to that last restriction, as arc hospitals, if the believer involved is dying or ser- iously ill. 
Other curbs, however, seem to Wes­ tern eyes to go to the heart of the prac­ tice of religion: 
“ Religious centers, religious asso­ ciations and servants of cults (clergy) are forbidden: 
“ A) To o rg a n iz e sp e cia l p ra y e r meetings for children, young people or women, as well as circles, groups and meetings for the study of religion; 
“ B) To organize pilgrimages of be­ lievers to so-called ‘holy p la ce s,’ to perform fraudulent actions with the aim of arousing su p erstitio n in the m asses of the population in order to extract by such a method any advan­ tages w hatsoever (announcem ent of 

Restrictions seem to he aim ed at preventing the use o f religion against the state 

 any type of m ira c le s , for ex a m p le , healing of sick people, prophesies, etc.); etc.); 
“C) To conduct compulsory exaction of dues and taxes from believers for the benefit of religious associations or for any other purposes; 
“ I)) To apply m easures of com pul­ sion or punishment to believers.” 
The book 
The book, “ Legislation on Religious 
Cults (Collection of Materials and Do­ c u m e n ts ) ,’’ w as co m p iled by V A. 
Kuroedov, chairm an of tho Council of 
Religious Affairs, and A.S. Pankratov, deputy prosecutor general of the Soviet 
Union. 
W estern sp ecialists who have exa­ mined it believe it to he authentic. 

It contains all the Soviet legislation on religion through 1971. with co m ­ m e n ta rie s and d e fin itio n s to guide functionaries. Soviet laws are not given general circulation, and the hook that reached the West is a numbered copy, one of 21,ooo. 
It is apparently intended as a guide to the Council for Religious Affairs, which supervises religion, and to police and court officials and local Soviets. 
The volume was smuggled out of the 
Soviet Union in September and given to the Rev. Michael Bourdeaux, director of Reston College in Kent 
Reston is a research center of eight scholars devoted to the study of religion in Communist countries. 
Privately financed, it receives money from the Ford Foundation, the Dutch 

Reformed Church, the Mennonite cen­ tral committee in the United States and similar organizations. 
Bourdeaux will not identity the man who b ro u g h t him th e hook — i t ’s number has been obliterated — except to say that he is a friend. 
Portions of the handbook, translated for The Washington Post Service, pro­ vide a rem arkable insight into religious life in the Sox let Union. 
One section says: “ Religious associa­ tions and servants of the cult . . do not have the right 
— 
“ A) To set up mutual aid funds or engage in charity work; 
“ Bi To organize sanatoriums or m e­ dical aid; 
“ (’) To a r r a n g e ex c u rsio n s, c h il­ dren’s playgrounds or sports grounds, to open libraries or reading-rooms; 
” 1)) To organize any sort of meetings, circles that are not related to the per­ formance of the cult.’’ 
CHURCH NEWS 
Church sponsoring m edical sessions 

The Florida Boys, one o f the to p nam es in gospel m usic for m ore than 2 o years, w ill p erform in co ncert at 7 :3 o p.m . Thursday in the Jefferson H igh 
School A u d ito riu m . The g ro up has p erform ed throughout the w orld. A lso perform ing w ith The Florid a Boys w ill be J. D. Sum ner and The Stam ps. 

St Andrew Presbyterian 
C hurch, 8231 C a lla g h an 
Road. will play host Sunday to three public sessions conducted by Reith McCaf- fety, emecutive director of the Medical Benevolence 
Foundation. 

McCaffety will speak al 
9:3o and l l a m. and 7:3o p.m. at the church. 
Upper classmen from the 
University of Texas Health 

S cience C e n te r in the schools of medicine, den­ tistry and nursing will at­ tend a buffet supper at ti 3o p.m. 
Founded 12 years ago, 
MBF is a group of medical and business people from throughout the South, in­ terested in up-grading the medical services of hospi­ tals and medical centers in under-developed areas of 

 the world 
Past efforts have readied into Africa. Asia. the near 
East, islands of the C am b bean, and C e n tra l and 
South America. 
The public is invited to attend all of the sessions. 
Buffet reservations can he made bv calling the church office al 341-4441.

TY death: No step forward 

Some proponents and op­ ponents of capita] punish­ ment have gone on record in recen t d ay s favoring 
D is tric t J u d g e W illiam 
Taylor’s ruling that free­ dom of the press under the first amendment demands perm ission for televising the state’s killing of men in the electric chair. 
The idea has been sug­ gested by prom inent n a­ tional political leaders such as John Connally as a de­ terrent to capital crim e for the public to actually see people dying in the electric chair on (heir television sets. 
The issue was joined by a suit filed by newsman Tony 
Garrett of Dallas Public 
Television. Some of the per­ sons scheduled to be exe­ cuted such as J e rry Lane 
Jurek have called for their executions to be telecast. 
Attorney G eneral John 
Hill has stated his opposi­ tion to the telecasting and promised to take it to court on the “ narrow issue” of electronically reporting the execution by television. 
Some opponents of capi­ tal p u n ish m en t have felt that the scene would be so 

 ghastly as to stir the indig­ nation of the general public toward abolishing capital punishment as an option for the state. 
O th ers h ave su g g e ste d the telecasting of a reen ­ a c tm e n t of th e c r im e in order to increase the possi­ bilities of deterring future crim e by showing men dy­ ing in the electric chair. 
It’s obvious that men of moral concern differ on the issue. It is necessary to ex­ am ine carefully the possi­ ble effects of such a step from the standpoint of w hat would increase respect for human life and sensitize p erso n s to th e v a lu es of living a life of o rd er and respect for others. 
Commonplace 
A look back to the days when pu b lic ex e cu tio n s w ere co m m o n p la c e d is ­ courages any idea that such violent s p e c ta c le s d e te r c rim in a l ac tio n s . In the brutal days of y estery ear all executions were public. 
E n g lan d was fam ous for them.

Jimmy R. Allen

C a p ita l c r im e s w ere n ev e r d e c re a s e d in any provable way by such acti- i~T vity. The classic historical ex am p le is the fact that people w ere ex ecu ted in public hangings for picking pockets in England in the 
Middle Ages. The crowds that gathered to watch the han g in g of p ick p o ck e ts w ere fav o rite p la ce s for pickpockets to work. 
The g rad u al erosion of resistan c e to violence by exposure to violence is now already hearing its bitter 

 fruit in our society. The television m edium is hav­ ing a powerful impact far beyond the imagination of most of us. 
The constant portrayal of violence already is produc­ ing fear-filled people and persons who are triggered into violent activity. 
To make the ultimate of that activity; that is, the actual killing of a hum an being on television screens, an ap p ro v a b le act has a ghastly possibility of re s­ toring the atm o sp h ere of the Roman circu s to con­ te m p o ra ry A m erica in a brutalization process u n ­ paralleled in hum an h is ­ tory. 
Those who propose d e ­ picting the execution of a human being on television have overlooked the p ro ­ pensity of human nature to enjoy th e feeling of v e n ­ geance and vindictiveness. 
Punishment should always have as its u ltim ate goal the protection of society atid the upholding of law. 
It should not simply he a legalized m e a n s for r e ­ venge. 
It s a subtle point, hut the 

 very feelin g s th a t a re s tirr e d in the h u m an psyche y earn in g for v en ­ geance against people on whom indignation centers will be unleashed in unpar­ alleled w ays by sueli an event. Those who hope to get indignation against the practice built to fever pitch are yearning for more than human nature will produce. 
The actual result will he a bu ild in g of fee lin g s of vengeance and vindictive­ ness into a society which has come a long way in its effort to understand that de­ terring crim es is more im ­ portant than venting wrath 
Som e d efin itiv e d if fe r ­ ence must be discerned le­ gally between the printed m edia and the electronic 

 media There is an im m e­ diacy of emotional impact about the electronic media w hich h as been played down by tin* courts and ig­ nored by m any of its r e ­ p o rte rs and ex e cu tiv es. 
There is a qualitative dif­ ference between the impact of the printed m edia and the electronic media 
It is erroneous to claim that every kind of reporting is alike and should have equal access to the event. 
The issue of capita! pun­ ishment is a complex one, hut telecasting the events opens the door to a regres­ sion to the Middle Ages in our social behavior. The re­ sult will hi* not a sensitized co n scien ce hut a s e a re d one.

WASHINGTON (A P) - 
The Episcopal Church or­ dains its first black female priest Saturday, some 172 years after the first black man was ordained into the priesthood, 
“ The Holy Spirit iii our ch u rch m o v e s slowly at times, but it does move," 
Dr. P auli M urray said before her ordination She added that the 
Rev. 
Absalom Jones was 58 w hen he was finally ordained and she s “ only eight y e a rs older than he was at the time.” 
The Rev. M u rray , of 
Alexandria, Va., will he one of six o rd in a ls at the Wa­ shington C a th ed ral c e r ­ em onies, including two other women. The ordina­ tions of two women, which took place lust year before the church officially a p ­ proved female priests, also will be recognized during the ceremonies. 

About 3(1 ordinations of 
Episcopal wom en are scheduled (his month, in­ cluding that of an acknow­ ledged lesbian iii New York on Monday. 
Cont tov e r s y co n tin u es over the acceptance of wornem priests, however, with dissent being voiced at 

 t h e ceremonies iii various places, 
“This is causing heart­ ache among a large num ­ ber of our people." re­ flected Bishop Wilburn C. 
Cam pbell. “ But I’m con­ vinced our Lord does not call people to the priest­ hood on the basis of sex, hut on the basis of commitment 

 t O l l IHI " 
Most recently Dr M ur­ ray was the 
Stu I berg professor of law and poli­ tics at Brandeis University. 
Slie resigned her post in 
1973 to become a candidate for th** holy orders iii the 
Episcopal (’hurch.

NEW YORK - Stock traders did some cau­ tious bargain hunting 
F riday, g iv in g the market a modest gain for the second straight session. 
Tho Dow Jones average of HO industrial sleeks rose 
3 24 to 983 13 after a I SU advance on Thursday. 
But the closely watched indicator of market trends nonetheless finished the first week of 1977 with a net loss of 21 52 points. 
C ontrast 
That showing contrasted sharply with the 19-and 
53-point jumps recorded by the Dow in the first five trading davs of 1975 and 
1978 
G ainers outnum bered losers by about a 4-3 m ar­ gin in Friday's tally of New 
York Stock Exchange is­ sues 
Big 
Board volum e 

 dropped off to 21 72 million shares from 23.92 million on Thursday. 
Analysts said some buy­ ing was prom pted by encouragem ent over the m arket’s relatively steady behavior Thursday in the afterm ath of the surprise selloff over the first three days after New Year’s 
They also noted general approval of D ecem ber chain-store sales figures issued Thursday, as well as the governm ent’s report 
Friday afternoon that con­ sumer credit expanded by 
$1.24 million in November 

W aiting 
A number ot investors, meanwhile, seemed to hold off any major activity dur­ ing the day aw aiting 
President -elect C arte r's economic proposals. 
.lust after the NYSE close 
(a rte r and leading 
Democrats from Congress announced a proposal for a 
$39 billion combination of tax cuts and spending over 

 the next two years. 
Standard & Poor’s index of 4oo ind u strial stocks slipped .o5 to 116.54, and 
S&P’s 5oo-stock composite index eased OI to 1o5 OI. 
Bauseh & Lomb, the most active NYSE issue, jumped more than 4 points and Na­ tional Patent Development rose a fraction in active trading in the American 
Stock Exchange. 
Bauseh A Loinb said the two companies had settled all their legal disputes over the soft contact lens busi­ ness, and National Patent said it would introduce a soft lens in the 
U.S. market. 

General Electric, which announced an internal reorganization plan, climbed nearly a point in active trailing. 
National Semiconductor lost a fraction to the 25 level after a 
1 4 -point drop 
Thursday, when the com­ pany reported sharply lower quarterly earnings.

Coastal owns Zenith oil 

HOUSTON (AP) — Coastal States (,as 
Corp. reported Friday a subsidiary owned the fuel oil aboard the tanker Grand Zenith that has been missing in the North Atlantic more than a week. 
Another subsidiary also was said lo have been using the tanker under an agreement to charter the vessel through a third party 
It is lh*- second time within a month for a 
( oastal States subsidiary to be involved in 
Atlantic tanker mishaps 

Coastal Mates confirmed earlier that a third subsidiary served as a broker for tho cargo of 146,llliil barrels of fuel oil aboard the tanker Argo M erchant that ran aground Dec 15 off M assachusetts to cause one of the largest oil spills in history along the the Atlantic Coast. 
Both tankers carried No. 6 fuel oil, a heavy oil used iii power generating plants, scheduled for delivery to M assachusetts firms 
Soybean prices firm 

Soybeans firm ed th is w eek in response to several factors, not the least of which was a speech made in Florida on Thursday by 
A ssistant 
A gricultu re 
Secretary Richard Bell. 
* 
He asserted that beans could be in short supply before a new crop is har­ vested next fall 

He also indicated that according to current avai­ lable d ata, world food stocks arc more likely lo decline than increase. 
Also contributing to the strength in prices were re­ ports that the Peoples Re- pubbc of China might be bidding for over 8oo,ooo metric tons of beans 
The grain market in Chi­ cago had a generally firm undertone following both the lead of soybeans and the

BUSINESS DIGEST 

 consumer demand. 
Organized boycotts, some of which were initiated by grocery chains, would have the effect, ll successful, of cutting coffee usage i i i the 
United Statee while 1 ii - creasing the demand for tea and cocoa. 
Coffee beans tor delivery in May dropped by 12 cents during the last three ses­ sions of the last three ses­ sions of the week. 
Since the severe frost hit 
Brazilian trees in July 1975. world quotations have climbed steadily 
That nation’s production suffered a 66 per cent cut this year to only seven mil­ lion bags. 
Since there is a three to four year lag while new trees come on line, prices may he firm for some time to come 

Port doesn’t want 
Alaskan tankers 

C O M PIlfD FROM WIRE SERVICES 
SEATTLE — Two representatives of Clallam County, 
Wash , groups gave an Interior Department hearing on a 
Sohio Alaskan oil facility proposal the same message: don’t consider us an alternative. 
Also, the director of the Washington state Energy 
Office said interests other than those of Standard Oil of 
Ohio should bt* considered 
The hearing Thursday was on a draft environmental impact statement for the proposal to bring Alaskan crude from Valdez, Alaska, to Long Beach. Calif., via tanker than fui to Midland. Tex., by pipeline for distribution to the 
Midwest. 
One alternative to Long Beach is Port Angeles, county seat of Clallam, described by the statement as “one of the best deep water situations on the West Coast.” It would be linked to the Midwest by pipeline. 
Federal wom en’s hank nixed 

WASHINGTON — The U.S. comptroller of the currency has denied an application to set up (he nation’s first federally chartered women’s bank in downtown Washing­ ton 
The applicants, who include several Washington busi­ nesswomen and educators, were told that as a group they lacked the qualifications to run a bank and failed to show the economic potential to make one profitable, according to a letter from the comptrollers’ office. 
Convictions overturned 

PHILADELPHIA — A federal appeals court has thrown out price-fixing convictions against four gypsum board manufacturers and three ext'cutives. 
The split decision Thursday by the 3rd U.S Court of 
Appeals overturns the July 1975 convictions of United 
States Gypsum Co.; National Gypsum Co.; Georgia-Pacific 
Corp ; Ceiotex Corp ; Colon Brown, chairman of the hoard of directors of National Gypsum; J .P. Nicely, retired 
National Gypsum vice president for sales; and Andrew J. 
Watt, executive v ice president of United States Gypsum. 
Suit on Texaco urged 

AUSTIN — The Texas Air Control Board has asked Atty 
Gen John Hill to sue Texaco. Inc., for allegedly violating anti pollution standards at its Port Arthur plant. 
The board said it also was asking Hill to sue Tompkins 
Coatings, Inc., of Houston for alledged violations of the 
Texas Clean Air Act 
Texaco allegedly' violated a rule which prohibits a com­ pany from storing a volatile carbon compound in a sta­ tionary tank with a capacity of more than 25,o9o gallons unless vapor loss can bi* prevented 
Finance firms want hike 

AUSTIN — Sen Bill Patm an said Friday finance companies want the 1977 legislature to enact a bill raising their “ extra-high rates” by 25 per cent even though their own burrowing costs have gone down dramatically in the past two years. 
Hearing set on gas suit 

AUSTIN — The Texas Railroad Commission has scheduled a Jan 18 hearing lo decide whether to ask the attorney general to sue the community of Appleby and five gas distributing companies for allegedly violating com­ mission safety regulations 
The com panies involved are Rimrock Gas Co. of 
Amarillo, McLeod Gas Co of McLeod, Dick Dowling Gas 
Co of Sabine Pass, Junction Natural Gas Co. of Junction and Southwest Gas Distributors, Inc of Haywood. 

Dollar regains all losses for week 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
LONDON 
- 
The dollar rallied Friday to recoup all its losses a gain st m ajor E uro­ pean curren cies ear­ lier this week. 

The price of gold rose slightly alter sharp drops over the previous two days. 
European dealers, said general reappraisal of U.S. interest rate prospects was the m ain reason for the dollar’s increased strength. 
The dollar was also helped, they said, by news from the economic strong­ man ol Europe, West Ger­ many, that told of higher unem ployment, lower in ­ dustrial output and lack of foreign demand on order books. 
Gold closed at $133 an ounce in London against 
$132.75 T hursday. In Zu­ rich. Europe’s other main bullion center, it closed at 
$133,623 against $132,875. 

Tuesday gold closed at what dealers term ed an 
“artificially high” price of 
$136,125 in Zurich and $136 in London. 

The dollar closed higher 

Friday against E urope’s two strongest currencies, the West German mark and the Swiss franc. 
The U .S. currency bought 
2.3653 marks in Frankfurt against only 2.35 Thursday 
Airline sets new passenger record 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRtST *IEW S 

DALLAS — Southwest 
Airlines set another record in December when it car­ ried 136,137 p assengers between Dallas, Houston, 
San Antonio and the Rio 
Grande Valley. 
The total represented an increase of 41 per cent over the 96,271 passengers car­ ried during December 1975. 
Southwest flew 35,725,424 revenue passenger m iles during last month, or an increase of 4o per cent over the 25.582.o8o flown in the same month of 1975. 
New records were also 

 attained during the fourth q u a rte r of 
1976 when 
Southwest carried 4o7,626 passengers, com pared to 
3o9,719 passengers carried during the same quarter of 
1975, 

Southwest carried 1,539,- 
113 passengers during 1976, which represents a 35 per cent increase over the 
1,136.318 passengers c a r­ ried during 1975. 

Southwest experienced a 
36 per cent increase in revenue passenger miles in 
1976 over 1975.

C H IC A G O ( A P ) - C o m m e rcial selling believed of a hedging n atu re, erased sm all q ain and produced a 21? cent loss in w heat futures on the Chicago Bo ard of 
T rad e F rid a y 
Corn p ric es closed on a m ixed tone but oats lost about I 1 j cents 
Soybean futures traded in a n a rro w ra n g e cit about 7 cents and closed on an uneven tone 
Soybean m eal prices w e re little changed at the ti nal bell, as w e re soybean oil p rices, Iced b ro ilers closed n a rro w ly m ixed 
The hedging in the w heat pit topped oft cession of ra th e r slow trad e in w heat 
Pric e s had m oved in a n a rro w rang e after the g o vern m en t had reported that export co m m itm en ts last w eek showed little chanqe in w h eat 
The hedge selling at the close w as by som e w h eat m ille rs, elevato rs and an exporter 
Another factor In the w h eat selling w as report of m ore snow tor the w inter w h eat a re a of the Southw est 
The snow report, h o w e ver, tended to bring buyers into the soybean co m p lex , corn and oats 
These com m o dities w ould be ted to snow bound livestock In g re a te r am ounts 
In the closing m inutes as w h eat selling expanded corn and o ats w eaken ed , also losing e a rly gains 
Soybean oil and m eal cam e under m ild profit taking and this, com bined w ith the w eakness in g rain s, tended to in flu en ce late selling in lo yb e a n s

Educators protest IRS plan 

WASHINGTON (AP) - A parade of educators and two members of the House tax-writing committee as­ sailed on Friday an Inter­ nal Revenue Service propo­ sal that would tax free tui­ tion benefits received by spouses and children of some school, college and university employes. 
Private schools common­ ly provide tuition-free education to em ployes’ dependents, sometimes on a reciprocal basis between schools. The value of these benefits has not previously been taxed, but a pending 
IRS proposal would levy income tax on them as a form of income. 

No rush 
IRS Commissioner Don­ ald Alexander, who is due to leave office in less than two wdeks, said the agency would not “ rush to judg­ 

 ment on this very serious m atter.” 
T ypically recu rrin g in the comments of the scores of educators on a daylong witness list at a IRS public hearing were predictions that such a tax would: 
• Make it h ard er to recruit faculty and staff; 
• Break promises made years ago to employes who took jobs while counting on free tuition; 
• Shift the cost of educating children of low er-paid clerical and maintenance employes to the governm ent, because such employes wouldn’t be able to accept free tuition becall*1 of the tax cost. 
Rep. Abner Mikva, D-Ill., a m em ber of the House 
Ways and 
M eans 
C om m ittee, said any change in the tax status of such tuition paym ents ought to be made by Con­ 

 gress, not the IRS. 

Mikva said Congress had relied on long-standing IRS policy not to tax such payments. He said he would like to try to get Congress to pass legislation specifically exem pting such payments from tax. 
Any change in tax policy on indirect employe ben­ efits ought to bi* consistent, 
Mikva said, pointing out that Congress had recently exempted from income tax the value of legal services provided to w orkers by their em ployers through group plans. 
He also referred to such other non-taxed benefits as store discounts given to some employes of retailers and low-cost or free travel available to a irlin e em ­ ployes. 
Rep. Jam es G. M artin, 
R-N.C., also a Ways and 
Means 
C om m ittee 

 m em ber, said the parent student. 
....... ought not be taxed for a 
11 is not >’et known what of such a change in benefit received by a v>ew ^ incoming C arter regulations. 

 administration might take tax

Cabinet choice reveals his financial worth 

WASHINGTON (AP) - 
Rep. Brock Adams, P re ­ sident-elect Carter’s choice for secretary of transporta­ tion, reported his net worth at $153,2o1.64 Friday. 
In a financial statement filed with the Senate Com­ merce Committee. Adams listed assets of $23o,213, in­ cluding two residences, furniture, three automo­ biles and 
KIO shares of 
American Telephone and 
Telegraph Co. stock. 
Adams went before the committee in a confirm a­ tion hearing Friday. 
Liabilities of $77,o11.7o included two mortgages to­ taling $72,5oo and $3,o21 balance on two loans for school tuition for his chil­ dren. 
A separate statem ent listed family cash assets totaling $33,716 iii check­ 

 ing and savings accounts, including sep arate ac­ counts of his wife, 
E lizabeth, and three children. 
Adams filed copies of his federal income tax returns for 1973, 1974 and 1975. 

The returns showed ad­ justed gross income of 
$69,632 and federal income tax of $13,52o in 1973, in­ come of $59,624 and tax of 
$11,118 in 1974. and income ol $62,93o and tax of $14,974 for 1975. 

I ii addition to h i s con­ gressional salary of $42,5oo in 1973 and 1974 and $42,85o in 1975, the joint returns of 
Brockman and Elizabeth S. 
Adams listed income from honoraria, articles, and lectures totaling $2o,576 in 
1973, $15,368 in 1974 and 
$17,824 in 1975.

Ex-Mossier spouse loses claim to will 

HOUSTON (AP) - A probate judge ruled Friday the last husband of Candace 
Mossier has no legal stand­ ing lo challenge the will of the late millionairess. 
Judge 
Pat 
Gregory rejected Barnett Garrison's claim he is the surviving spouse. 
Garrison, 38, and Mrs. 
Mossier were m arried in 
1971, and divorced Dec. I, 
1975. 
The will in question divides an estim ated $27 million estate equally among three of six ch il­ dren. 
After th eir m arriag e, 
Garrison fell from the roof of their River Oaks home and received injuries that left him virtually an in­ valid 
Ben II. Schledier, attor­ ney for G arrison, had a r­ guta the divorce was never final and that Garrison, as the surviving spouse at the tim e of M rs. M ossler’s death in Miami, Fla., last 
October, has legal standing to contest the will. 

 moon, was reported in sa­ tisfactory condition Friday following triple bypass sur­ gery at the Texas Heart In­ stitute. 
“ Ile is still in in test vc care but is doing very well,” said a spokesman at 
St. Luke's Episcopal Ho­ spital. 

“ His condition is stable and there are no complica­ tions.” 
The spokesman said the surgery involved the re­ placement of three vein seg­ ments with veins removed from Irwin's legs. 
Module pilot 

Irwin was the lunar module pilot on the Apollo 
15 m ission of .July 26 to 
Aug. 7. 
1971. 
He and 
Astronaut David R Scott made the first use of a lun­ ar roving vehicle for m ovement about the moon's surface. Alfred M. 
Worden, tin* third member of the crew, continued iii lunar orbit aboard the command module as Scott and Irwin made their lunar explorations. 
Irwin, 46, now a resident of Colorado Springs, Colo., resigned from the astron­ aut corps on May 23. 1972 
A native of Pittsburgh. 
Pa., Irwin was a test pilot at Edwards Air Force Base. 
Calif., when he became an astronaut in Aped 1966 
Services are set for civic leader 

Funeral services for Mrs. 
Henry ll. Bryant, 236 VV. 
Summit Ave., will be at I p m. Saturday in Porter 
Loring Mortuary. 
Mrs. Bryant, daughter of the late Mr. and M rs. 
Walter C. Moore, died Fri­ day. 
She was a member of the 
First Presbyterian Church, past president of the Wo­ men of the Church, Junior 
League, P ro testan t C hil­ d re n s’ Home and Texas 
C hildrens Home Finding 
Society. 
Mrs. Bryant was an hon­ orary member of the Battle of Flowers Assn , the Laur­ el Heights Garden Club and mistress of the robes for 

 coronation for the Order of the Alantol 
She was a past president of 
T im ely 
T opics, a m em ber of the Fenwick 
Club, D aughters of the 
A m erican 
R evolution, 
Magna Charta Dames and 
National Society of Colonial 
Dames of America. 
Mrs. Bryant is survived by two daughters, Mrs. 
John M. Browning of San 
Antonio and Mrs. Donald 
Test of Dallas; a sister, 
Mrs. Douglas McGregor of 
El Paso; five gran d ch il­ d ren, and four g reat grandchildren. 
There will be a private burial in Mission Burial 
Park.

16o6 block of La Manda boulevard, police said. A resident of the home told officers a man was attem pt­ ing to tear off the screen door and enter shortly be­ fore the shooting. 
Riley was shot once in tin* chest. A large-caliber pistol was recovered at the scene, police reported.

Cleo Gibbs, 42, of 1622 La 
Manda Boulevard. He was 

 released from Bexar Coun­ ty Jail after posting a $5,ooo bond set by Night Magis­ trate Manuel Lopez. 
Man charged

The victim, Jerald Perry, 
33, of 35o2 Culebra Road, was listed in poor condition at Bexar County Hospital with m ultiple gunshot wounds. Police said he had been shot four times in the 

 face and chest. 
Witnesses told police the 
2:37 a m. shooting followed an argum ent between two men at a residence in the 
2oo block of G ladstone 
Avenue. Officers said a .22 caliber pistol was used in the incident.

Gladstone Ave. He was re­ leased from Bexar County 
Jail after posting a $5,ooo bond set by Lopez.

Homecraft offers Woodstone home 

H o m e c r a f t o p e n e d th e 
A m e r i c a n a a s th e fir s t tw o-story m o d e l in W ood- ston e. T h e h o m e fe a tu r e s three bedroom s, in clu d in g an enorm ous m a ster suite, a n d a fo u r th b e d r o o m , which, of course, can be put to a n u m b e r of d iffe r e n t u s e s s u c h a s a s t u d y or p a r lo r . T h e p lan a ls o in ­ c l u d e s 1 12 b a t h s a n d a two-car garage.
