San Antonio EX P R ESS-N EW S— 
Saturday January 8 1977 
Braun Station East presents new series 

A “ first” for modern housing in the San An­ tonio area will be fea­ tured this weekend by 
La Mansion Homes in 
Braun Station East. 
The long-established, re­ putable building firm will present the first "Energy 
Efficient Homes” in Bexar 
County as its five houses await the personal inspec­ tion of home hunters who are shopping for a resi­ dence that lets them enjoy the luxuries of a quality home and, at the same time, not have to worry about overusing utilities! 
‘Answer’ 
La Mansion Homes has provided the best possible answer to their desires and needs. The "Energy E ffi­ cient Home” has it all for them this weekend, and what’s most surprising, perhaps, is that La Mansion 
Homes itself has not named this innovative, economical and even affordable series of housing. 
The term "Energy Effi­ cient Hom e" is given to these Braun Station East homes by Owens-Coming, the firm that personally in­ spected each of the five 

 featured this weekend be­ fore the sign identifying them as "E n e rg y E ffi­ cient” could be shown in the front yards. 
They are named appro­ priately and priced affordably. This weekend, only La Mansion Homes 
Inc., with houses expertly built by veterans VV. J. 
McCarthy Jr. & Son, has them ready for showing. 
Outstanding energy-sav­ ing features in La Man­ sion’s new series include 
Fiberglas insulation rated 
R-26 in ceilings and K l3 in walls, both with vapor bar­ riers; insulated doors with special seals to reduce air 

VICTOR F. BUTSCHEK 

 infiltration; windows with caulking and sealing at various critical locations to reduce air infiltration; thermostatically controlled power vents in attics; cen­ tral air conditioning and heating not oversized and engineered on the job for each house; and strategic location of wincows. There is no plumbing inside the was; all insulation is solid! 

Even more construction items which result in en­ ergy savings for residents can be explained this wee­ kend in Braun Station East. 
All five homes are along 
Wickersham in the north­ western 
Bexar County community off Bandera 
Road north of N.W. Loop 
4 IO. 
La Mansion, of course, is well aware that today’s home hunters are looking for more than energy-sav­ ing features. That’s why these homes fully measure up to the standards the custom building firm set in other recent San Antonio neighborhoods. 
Handsomely rugged ex­ teriors of IOO per cent ma­ sonry with trim, planting areas, partitions for plant­ ing areas and various styles 

 can be seen among these five homes alone. 
Inside can be seen excit­ ing, comfortable floor plans of three or four bedrooms and two baths. Color-coor­ dinated kitchen with lu­ minous lighting, countertop range, built-in oven, vented hood, disposer and dish­ washer is standard. All cooking facilities wear the dependable Magic Chef brand name except one, the big bonus: a Litton M i­ crowave Oven! 
Other luxury features in­ clude a woodburning, all­ brick fireplace in a living room, carpeting through­ out, beamed cathedral ceiling, spacious master suite, baths with Venitian marble vanities of one piece and large two-car garages. 
Consider the outstanding 
Energy Efficient features as well as the luxury items so desirable and it means homes definitely for the fu­ ture which are available 

ARAUN STATION EAST is where ‘Energy Efficient Hom es’ are being introduced 

Victor Butschek named 
Homecraft division head 

Victor P. Butschek 
J r . has been named president of the 
Schertz-Austin 
Di­ vision of H om ecraft 
Corp., the largest home builder and de­ veloper in San Antonio. 
The newly formed 
Schertz-Austin Division consists of six major sin­ gle-family residential com­ munities located in Austin, 
.Schertz and Round Rock. 
The developments include 
Northeliffe Country Club 
Estates, Northeliffe and 
Northeliffe East — totaling 
#o5 acres with an 18-hole championship golf course. 
The three communities 

 sold in excess of $1 million of new homes on opening d a y last October. In addi­ tion, three communities are located in metropolitan 
Austin: Mesa Village, a 
I H3-lot development in 
Round Rock; Forest Bend, a 274-lot community now under construction in southeastern Austin; and 
Southwest Park, a 218-lot community in southwestern 
Austin. 
Prior to coming with 
Homecraft Corp in Ja n ­ uary. 1976 as a vice Dresi- dent of Land Development, 
Butschek owned and oper­ ated Advance Real Estate, 
Advance Homes and Ad­ vance Insurance. 

Homecraft Corp. is the 

 largest privately owned home building and land de­ veloping firm in the nation. 
It has major single-family residential communities in ll Texas cities, including 
Houston, San Antonio, Aus­ tin. Schertz, Brownsville, 
McAllen. Mission. La Fer­ ia, Beaumont and Round 
Rock Homecraft is also the largest builder in Louisian­ an with several commun­ ities in metropolitan New 
Orleans. 

The company’s outstand­ ing housing record includes the sale of more than 2,3oo single-family and/or patio homes in 29 communities over the past three years for revenues exceeding $87 million. 

 today. The very reasonable price range starts as low as 
$45,ooo! 

There is no better setting for these new homes than 
Braun Station East, where two tennis courts are being added to the recreational facilities of the club which already features a swim­ ming pool pavilion, a com­ petition-sized pool and a privacy fence enclosing the facilities within walking distance of these homes. 

Braun Station East is also near numerous points of destination, including em- ciASityuD p im A T 

 ployment centers like UT- 
SA, USAA, South Texas 
Medical Center and the 
Methodist and Veterans 
Administration hospitals. 
Even Lackland and Kelly 
AFBs are just a short drive away. Major shopping faci­ lities are nearby in subur­ ban Leon Valley and along 
N AV. Loop 41o.

Loop 
41o onto 
Bandera 
Road and proceeding north of Leon Valley. Large signs mark the entrance to the community at Braun Road.

Home by Morton / South­ west. In fact, they gain all they’ve ever wanted!

 is figured into an attracti­ vely affordable' package in a price range starting as low as $27,ooo.

Other extras Morton / 
Southwest has made avail­ 

 able in the 
Freedom 
Homes scries are wall-to- wall closets with storage space extending all the way to the ceiling and sliding doors of panel designs, fin­ ished two-ear garages, uti­ lity and work areas, patios led to by sliding glass doors, clever blends of ma­ sonry and wood for striking exteriors, carpeting of the buyers’ choice of colors, efficient Friedrich central air and heat systems and, in most, fireplaces.

Units at Antonian boast French styles 

Want to move to a quiet spot where you will have lots of room? 
Antonian 
Apartments answer this question best, and, despite the unusual quiet, the location is convenient, too. 
Roomiest 
The units in this complex are some of the biggest and roomiest in northwestern 
San Antonio. 
The one-bedroom, one- bath apartments are a spa­ cious 1,o27 sq. ft ; the two- bedroom, one-bath mea­ sures 1.185 sq. ft.; and the two-bedroom, two-bath apartments are 1,235 sq. ft. 
Antonian is a relaxing place to live, set hack as it is from the street on Fre­ dericksburg Road. Traffic noise is unnoticed. Resi­ dents like its location be­ cause it is convenient to 
USAA and the South Texas 
Medical Center. City bus service is available. 
At Antonian, there are 
225 apartment units. 
Big walk-in closets pro­ vide wonderful storage space at Antonian. 
Antonian 
Apartments were built by Dwight Lieb. 
Owner is Life Investors.

Sen Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday January 8 1977General Development opens new office in S.A. 

I, . V V v 
- 
V. 

CAMELOT com m unity features choice location 

Cam elot’s location makes it ‘fop area 

It’s often been said that Ray Ellison’s Ca­ melot offers something for everyone. Indeed, few neighborhoods can come closer than Ca­ m elot to fitting that description. 
Located in San Antonio’s desirable northeastern a r­ ea, Camelot is situated midway between Fort Sam 
Houston and Randolph 
AFB, m aking the neigh­ borhood the ideal choice for military families. 
Shopping areas 
The beautiful new Wind­ sor Park Mall is just min­ utes away. This gigantic shopping complex and other smaller shopping ar­ eas nearby put nearly every kind of store and serv ice a short drive away. 

Easy access to N E. Loop 
41ft and 
N.E. 
Ill 
35 expressways provides con­ venient routes to other 
North Side and downtown shopping and business dis­ tricts. 
Preferred school districts serve the Camelot area. 
Recreational facilities and churches nearby provide important centers of family activities within the imme­ diate area. 
Ray Ellison’s new homes in Camelot also provide joyful family living. Con­ venience is everyw here. 
Every home features a built-in electric kitchen with range, vent, d ish ­ washer and garbage dis­ poser. 
Central heat and air conditioning provide com­ fort the year around. And energy-saving features help save you money on utility 

 coats. 
Many decorator touches are available, including woodburning fireplaces, cathedral ceilings and high quality Armstrong floor co­ verings and carpeting. 
The homes are finished in beautiful brick and native stone, com plem ented by outdoor patios, professional landscaping and fencing. 
A wide variety of prices is available in Camelot, with new homes starting in the high 2os. No city taxes means lower monthy pay­ ments, and, if you buy now , there are no monthly pay­ ments until April. 
Drive out to Camelot to­ day. Take N E. IH 35 to the 
Walzem Road exit, drive east on Walzem and follow the signs to the furnished models open dailv until 8 p.m. at 823ft New World Dr. 

General 
D evelop­ ment Corp., the lead­ ing com m unity de­ veloper in Florida and one of the nation’s lar­ gest, has opened re­ gional offices in San 
Antonio at 41o Place. 
Ted Weiss is the regional m anager at the office, 
Babcock Road and N.W. 
Loop 41ft. 
Homesites 

The corporation offers homesites now, or later, for retirem ent. Its prim e in­ terest is military families and, because of this, has its regional office in San An­ tonio, with its Army and 
Air Force installations, and maintains branch offices at two other military-oriented cities, El Paso and Killeen. 

In addition to offering homesites, General Deve­ lopment designs and builds homes with more than 3o styles, ranging in price from under $17,OOO to more than $9o,OOO. 

“ Our sales offices arc a part of the local business community, and we hire local people,” Weiss stated. 

Weiss noted that General 
Development is one of the nation’s oldest, largest and respected community de­ velopers and is regarded as an industry leader in meet­ ing its environmental obli­ gations. 

In Florida, General De­ velopment has developed seven communities that to­ tal 235,ooo acres — more than 38o square miles — and has spent more than 
$ I Oft million on environ­ mental preservation, land developm ent and w ater, gas and sanitation systems. 

The M iam i-based firm owns and operates six 

CLASSIFIED W W L A V 

18-hole championship golf courses, with a seventh under construction; two m ajor hotels; and other commercial enterprises in its communities. Its major 
Florida com m unities are 
Port Charlotte, Port Mala­ 

 bar, Port LaBelle and Port 
St. Lucie. 
General Development is a public corporation with some 1o,ooo stockholders owning approxim ately 
9,2oo,ofto shares, which are traded on the New York 

Stock Exchange, as well as the Midwest, Pacific Coast and Toronto Stock E x­ changes.

It’s Your Life 
Live it up, or downstairs, or both. 

We have one bedroom studios and flats designed to make it easy for you to live just the way you like. Our glamorous studios feature a living area downstairs with a woodburning fireplace for chilly nights, and a loft bedroom overlooking all. The flats give equal importance to living and sleeping rooms, plus a separate dining room and a large walk-ln closet. 
Whichever you choose, you'll enjoy the unique Woodbin lifestyle — a way to get away without leaving home. There’s lots of fresh a ir. . . quiet nights, three pools, tennis courts, and two clubhouses 
Plus.W oodhili’s location makes it easily accessible to almost anywhere: it s only one minute from 1-1o, three to neighborhood shopping at Colonies

IS SCHAEFER 
IHE OHLY HHILHER 
IH LAKESIBE? 

N 

 o. But he’s the one you want to talk to. You may 

 not have known it. But there arc two builders in Lake­ side. Schaefer is the one who puts the most quality into his houses. 
And who’s planning to keep the com munity a viable part of San 
Antonio for a long, long time. 
The only problem is, if you want to see a Schaefer home in 
Lakeside, you may have to look a little harder. W e’re going to tell you why it’s worth your while. 

Schaefer builds better homes. 
When we build a Schaefer home, we do a lot of little things that you can’t see after the house is finished. 
For example, we use solid copper wire instead of aluminum. We engineer our foundations to con­ form to the soil conditions you find in Lakeside. 

And we do other things that don’t just work better. They look better. Every Schaefer home in 
Lakeside has its own privacy fence. 
Our bathroom tile is ceram ic, and laid entirely by hand. And our cabinets are furniture-finished oak. 
Atter all, you learn a lot about what people want from a home when you’ve been building them for 2o years. 

W 

 hat about energy efficiency? When you buy a Schaefer home in Lake­ side, you can be sure your heating and cooling bills w on’t eat you alive. Because we design the air conditioning system that goes in your home especially for your home. We add extra attic ventila­ tion. And we place windows where they’ll do the most good and the least harm. 

Is Schaefer the only builder in 
Lakeside? No. But we think there’s just one builder you’ll be interested in. That’s Schaefer. Lakeside.

By RAY RAGSDELL pat SID* NT SA 
BOARD O f REALTORS 
Home financing through the mortgage is a complex subject almost all home buyers, sooner or later, come to grips with. 
Lot’s (leal with some of tho terminology associated with mortgages l>eoaiise tho language of lending of­ ten proves confusing for most people who do not di al with financing profession­ ally. 
Brief glossary 
What follows is a brief glossary of terms 
CLOSING — Completion of the real estate transac­ tion It includes such things as the signing of notes, de­ livery of deed, disburse­ ment of money connected with the sale as well as other financial adjust­ ments. 
CLOSING COSTS - Costs paid at the closing by the borrower, ordinarily in­ cluding such things as the origination fee, title insur­ ance, survey, escrow pay­ ments, attorney's fees and taxes 
COMMITMENT 
- 
Agreement to make a loan subject to conditions 

CONVENTIONAL LOAN 
— Most common mortgage loan. It is a loan that us not insured by the KHA Nor it is guaranteed by the VA 

ES( ROW PAYMENT - 
That part of the monthly mortgage payment held iii trust to pay for such things as taxes, mortgage insur­ ance and hazard insurance 
FEDERAL 
HOLSING 
ADMINISTRATION (FUA) 
— The agency of the federal government that insures mortgages meeting KHA standards and conditions 
EEE SIMPLE - Abso­ lute and unconditional sta­ tus of property ownership 
G. 
1. 
LOAN 
- 
A m ortgage loan that is guaranteed by the Veterans 
Administration. 
HAZARD INSURANCE 
— Insurance purchased to protect property against fire. wind and other ha­ zards. 
HOME 
MORTGAGE 
ULAN — A long-term loan pledging tin* pro|x*rty pur­ chased as security. There are three principal kinds. 
Loans insured by the FUA. 
Loans guaranteed by the 
VA and conventional loans. 
MEN — A legal claim held on property as security against a debt. 
MORTGAGE DISCOUNT 
— Also known as points, loan brokerage fee, or new loan fee These are equa­ lizers in the mortgage field to make a loan more at­ tractive to the lender One point equals one j>er cent til the mortgage amount. It is roughly equivalent to Lh of one per cent in terms of in­ terest yield For example, in order to get a lender to back an 8 per ('cut VA or 

FU A loan when the market rate is 8:U» per cent, the yield on the loan must be increase :Vj of one per cent bv a cash payment That added cash payment is known as a mortgage dis­ count. Federal law prohi­ bits charging points to 
FH A /VA borrowers. How­ ever, lenders are allowed to charge a one jut cent ori­ gination fee, 
NOTE 
— 
IVocumeiit which acknowl«>dges a debt' and promises to pav it 
ORIGINATION FEE - A fee paid to the lender for costs involved in taking a mortgage 
PREPAYMENT 
CLAUSE — Clause permit ting a borrower to repay a portion, or the remainder, of a loan before its final due date Sometimes a penalty must Im* paid if this right is exercised. 
QUITCLAIM DEED - \ deed in which the person granting it relinquishes any interest he has iii a proper­ ty at that time. 
SEARCHING THE TI 
TLF — Or title search An investigation to determine if a seller has .ill rights lo the property he is selling and to find out it there are any liens or claims against it. 
TITLE — A document iii dioat mg evidence of owner ship 
. TITLE INSURANCE — 
Itisurancc protecting the insured from any defects In a title. It also guarantees the work of a title company.

How to stake, guy newly planted trees 

By TERRY WILBOURN 

COU NTY EXTENSION HORTICULTURIST 
Staking or guying newly planted trees is a common landscape practice; however, not all transplanted trees need to be staked. 
Many young tree s will stand alone while o th ers won’t grow upright or stand ag ain st the wind without some type of support. 
Limit support 
A young tree will develop roots and branches better able to resist the wind if it is supported only enough to hold the trunk upright. Ex­ cessive staking, however, is harmful to young trees. 
The reasons for staking or guying trees are to give 

 protection, to anchor the trees, and to support them. 
Unnecessary staking is ex­ pensive, detracts from the la n d sca p e, and re q u ire s m ore m aintenance. U nsa­ tisfactory methods of sup­ port may weaken, deform or injure the trunk. 
P ro te c tio n of newly planted tree s from lawn mowers, vehicles and van­ dals is one reason for stak­ ing. Trees, that can stand alone, without support and with some thinning of the branches, may only need two or three guard stakes high enough to be seen. 
Another reason for stak­ ing a transplanted tree is to p rev e n t ex cessiv e tru n k m o v e m en t by the wind from b reak in g new roots growing into the surround­ ing soil. The frequent wa- 
Down to Earth 

Gardeners’ Questions— Answers 

By TERRY WILBOURN 
COUNTY EXTENSION HORTICUITURIST 
Iii regard to plant hardiness, what zone is San Antonio in? 
A ccord in g to USO A's 
Plant Hardiness /one Map, all of Bexar County is on the northern edge of /one 9. 
The average annual m ini­ mum tem peratures range from 2o° to 2o°. lf you have 

 lived here very’ long, I am su re you are aw are of a large fluctuation in te m ­ perature from the northern to the southern part of the county. 

 te rin g , needed the first season or two, often loosens the soil and contributes to the instability of the root system. Sufficient support may again be achieved by two or three short g uard sta k es. T ies, from the stakes to the trunk, would help anchor the tree and keep the roots firmly in the ground. The branches may need to be thinned to re ­ duce the top w eight and wind resistance. 
Most tre e s up to two inches in diameter, or with trunks not strong enough to hold the tree upright, can be s u p p o rted by a 
2-by-2-ineh sta k e d riv en firm ly into the g round about one foot from the trunk. Use stakes as short as possible but tall enough to keep the tree upright. 
Attach a single tie near the top of the stake. Use a wire run through a piece of g ar­ den hose, an elastic w eb­ bing or a plastic tie made for this purpose. Provide for flexible m ovem ent at the tying point, taking care not to ca u se ru b b in g or g ird lin g in ju rie s to the tru n k . P ru n e up to one th ird of the b ra n c h e s to com pensate for the roots lost in transplanting and to reduce weight and wind re­ sistance of the top. 
Trees up to four inches in diameter can be supported by two to three stakes. At­ tach the ties to the trunk and p ru n e as previously described. 
Single stakes should be on the side of the prevailing winds. When two support 

 stakes are used, place them on each side of the tree in a line at right angles to the prevailing w inds. Single stakes, leaning toward the prevailing winds, at an an­ gle of 3o d eg re es to the, tru n k are sa tis fa c to ry . 
S upport sta k e s m ay be needed only th ro u g h the first growing season or be­ fore new growth begins in the spring. Untie the tree to see if it stands erect with­ out support. Thinning the b ran c h es helps th e tre e stand alone. 
W rap p in g tru n k s and larger branches of newly planted trees aids recovery and reduces water loss and dam age from sun scald to the trunk. W rapping also provides partial protection against borers. Apply bur­ lap strip s or special tree w rapping dow nw ard in a spiral fashion. Overlap the covering for added protec­ tion. Reinforce the w ra p ­ ping by binding with twine starting at the bottom and winding upward in the op­ posite direction from the wrapping. 
Leave the w rap p in g on the tree for two years unless ft becomes unsight­ ly. The wrapping should be removed occasionally to in­ spect for possible canker a re a s , b o re rs, s c a le or o th e r in sects. T h e tre e should be rew rapped fol­ lowing inspection. 
The time and effort spent in properly planting and staking your trees will tre­ m en d o u sly in c re a se the success in grow ing your trees.

My Azalea leaves are show ing a reddening in color and som etim es spotting within the leaf. What could be the cause? 
Cold weather will cause this, and we have had plenty this w inter. Keep plants m ulched and hope that no stem and trunk 

 splitting from freezing has occurred. Freeze injury to the leaves is generally not too detrimental. 

Are the garden calendars for 1977 available yet? If so w here can I get one? 

They sure are. This year, recommended fruit and nut varieties were added. You can order one free copy by calling the county agent's office. A dditional c o p ies will cost you IS cents per copy and can be obtained 

 by writing to Agricultural 
C o m m u n ic a tio n s, 
Reed 
McDonald B ld g., C ollege 
S tation , TX 77843. 
R e­ member, the first calendar is free; pay 13 c e n ts for each copy ordered after the first.

Spy suspect is arrested in N.J. 

NEW ARK. N J 
(A F ) 
— A Russian em igrant was arrested 
F riday night and charged with passing secret inform a­ tion about the American space shuttle program to a Soviet agent posing as a 
U N. diplomat. 
Ivan 
Rogalsky, a form er Soviet seaman who came to the United 
States in I R71, was a r­ rested in Lakewood, not far from where he was living in rural southern 
New Jersey, according to 

Louis 
A. 
G iovanetti, special agent in charge of the FBI in New Jersey. 
The FBI in Washington said Rogalsky had in his possession at the time of his arrest some “ highly classified" documents from the RC/X Corp. space center at Prince­ ton. 
Rogalsky is accused of spying and conspiring to pass classified data to 
Yevgeniy Petrovich Kar­ pov. second secretary of the Soviet delegation to 
Czechs crack down strongly on dissidents 

VIENNA. Austria (AP) 
— 
The 
Czechoslovak 
Communist regim e ap­ pears to be striking hard ut an upsurge of dis­ sident activity which it claims is instigated by the West, analysts in neighboring z\ustria said 
Friday. 
Alleged operations of the the U.S. Central In­ telligence Agency and 
West Ciermay are given as excuses for the crack­ down, which coincides with sim ila r moves in 
East 
G erm any and 
Poland, the analysts say. 
The official party new­ spaper, 
Rude 
Pravo, warned 
Czechoslovak dissidents F riday that they would have to face the consequences if they block the advance of 
Communism and violate the laws of the Commu­ nist state. 
Aimed 
The w arning was aimed at those who. the paper said, "addressed various letters — seem­ ingly to Czechoslovak authorities, but in reality fabricated on orders of anti-Com m unist and 
Zionist centers — which 

 are subsequently published by the West's most reactionary news media." 

The warning coincided with the publication in a number of m ajor Wes­ tern newspapers of a manifesto carrying the names of more than IOO persons demanding that the Prague government respect human rights.

Last match begins 

HOUSTON 
(A P ) 
- 
C alifornia and Texas players of the Grand Na­ tional team moved into the final match of the 
North American Bridge 
Team playoff F rid ay with a decisive 296-2*15 victory over the Rei- singer Trophy Team. 
The Grand National team started play Friday night against the team that holds both the Van­ d e rb ilt 
Cup and the 
Springold Trophies for 
19 76 
Play continues through Sunda. 
The winner w ill represent North America and the Am erican Con­ tract Bridge League in 
1977 World Bridge Team championships at Manila in October 
Winners of the three day sem ifinal match were B illy Fisenberg, 
Paul 
Soloway, 
John 
Swanson, and 
Eddie 
Kantar, all of 
Los 
Angeles. Bob Ham m ar and Bobby Wolff, tnith of 
Dallas 
All six have been members of the Aces team that won the world title in 
197o-71 with 
Barnman. 
W olff and 
Fisenberg as members of that championship Loom.

Info charge begins 

You may not have need it, but Friday started paying for infor­ mation calls to the oper­ ator. 
The .new telephone numlier for directory as­ sistance in San Antonio was changed to 1411, as part of a statewide plan. 
The Texas Public Uti­ lity 
Com m ission ap­ proved the charge for directory assistance last month as part of a rate increase package. 
Each customer will Im* allowed IO calls to 1411 without extra charge during the m onthly b illin g period, a Bell spokesman said 
Beyond the free calls, custom ers w ill he charged 2o cents for each information call. 
The Bell spokesman said experience in other states indicated that 99 per cent of the customers will not"be affected by the new directory assistance charge. 
He added there has been no reports of com­ plaints during the swit­ chover period. 

 the United Nations. Kar­ pov has diplom atic im ­ m unity and cannot be arrested by U.S. authori­ ties. 
He was named as a eo-conspirator with 
Rogalsky by FBI Direc­ tor Clarence Kelley. 
Giovanetti said Karpov has long been suspected of being a member of the soviet Com m ittee for 
State Security — the 
KGB — and that lie probably would be asked to leave the 
United 
States. Karpov has been in this country since Nov. 
29. 1972. 
Lives in Bronx 

Karpov, who lives in a 
Soviet apartm ent com­ plex in the Bronx, N Y., was unavailable for com­ ment Friday night. 
Rogalsky, a 34-year-old unemployed mechanic, obtained the space shut­ tle information from an unidentified RCA engi­ neer who was secretly cooperating with the 
FBI. Giovanetti said 
He said some informa­ tion was passed to K ar­ pov, but nothing vital to 
U S. national security reached the Soviet Union. 
The stocky, sandy- haired Rogalsky. who faces the death penalty if convicted of the charges against him, smiled at photographers as he was led from 
FB I head­ quarters in Newark to a van for transportation to the Bergen County Jail. 
He was being held in the jail overnight, pend­ ing arraignm ent and a bail hearing Saturday before U.S. M agistrate 
William Hunt. 
Unemployed 

Giovanetti said 
Rogalsky came to the Lf- nited 
States through 
Spain and Germany on 
Dec. 15. 1971. He had been employed as an electrician and mechanic here but was not working at the time of his arrest, the agent said, 
He said Rogalsky, a bachelor, met the RCA engineer in November 
1975 at a party in 
California. Rogalsky ex­ pressed interest in the engineer's background and employment, aud iii 
July 1976. when the en­ gineer moved to New 
Jersey to work at the 
RUA plant in Pnm*eton. 
Rogalsky renewed his acquaintance, Giovanetti said. 
"Numerous meetings followed, and the em ­ ploye was encouraged on numerous occasions by 
Rogalsky to obtain infor­ mation from RCA, in ­ cluding information from the space shuttle sys­ tem ," Giovanetti said.

Youth is killed in 2-car crash 

A two-vehicle collision in Southeast Bexar Coun­ ty Friday claimed the life of a young man. 

Sheriffs deputies iden­ tified the victim as Jesus 
Jose Galindo, about 2o, of 
Bloomington. 
Galinao was rushed to 
Santa Rosa Hospital by 
FMS following the 3:9o p.m. accident He died of multiple injuries during emergency surgery a bl­ ite less than th roe-und­ one half hours later, a hospital spokesman said. 
Deputy Tomas Monte- mayor said the victim was a passenger id an 

 eastbound ear on EM 1518 driven by Argatindo Ga­ lindo, 42, of Presidio 
The vehicle was in col­ lision with a cur traveling southbound on 
Hwy. 181, driven by Juan 
Velasco Guzman, 4h, of 
248 Tedder Drive in San 
Antonio, the deputy said 
The Guzman ear was knocked 3o feet by the force of the collision ae- cording to Monteiuayor, 
Neither the older Ga- br)do, nor another pas­ senger in his ear nor the* iK'cupunts oi the Gu/muu car were seriously in ju red , 
M onteiuayor said.

 at Sit XI 

GRANT W ATCHES Vikings with stem look 

AP WIREPHOTOS 

LOS ANGELES - It hap* petted shortly before noon Fri­ day. Bud Grant, the one they call 
“ S to n efa ce,” sm iled through an interview and most o n he time he was smiling at his own lines. 

This is the M innesota c o a c h ’s fourth Super Bowl so perhaps it’s time for him to loosen up a bit. He did just that Friday. 
Oh, there w eren’t any knee-slap- pers and Bob Hope, won’t toss in his sleep tonight, worrying about the new funny m an. But. in his own way, 

✓ J IM M Y T U E C R E E K f a v o r s 
Oakland by 6 points 

G rant did display a new. relaxed, humorous side to his nature and he seemed to enjoy the presentation. 
In recent days there’s been much publicity about the fact that Minne­ sota blocked 15 kicks during the sea­ son. Some of that publicity told how 

 the Viking specialty team is hoping to 
/Odd to that number at Oakland’s ex­ pense Sunday. 
When asked about this goal Grant went into lengthy detail. 
“ Yes. i t ’s tru e th a t we have blocked lo and would like to make it ltf or 17 Sunday,” Bud said. And then he added, “ but it’s just as true that 
O ak lan d ’s Hay Guy didn t have a punt blocked all year. 
“ Yes, we’ll try to put a lot of pres­ sure on him Sunday but we’ll need som e help. like a low sn ap from center, which isn t likely to happen. 
Or maybe for Guy to fumble the snap, which isn’t likely to happen. Or per­ haps a missed blocking assignment, which also isn’t likely to happen,” 
G rant continued. His sm ile grew broader with the announcement.

Seattle hustles by Spurs 

By JIM HUTTON 
O f THI EXPRESS N E W S STAIE 

SEATTLE — For a change it was a sunny day in Seattle, but the Sonics left the Spurs in a fog after the third quarter Fri­ day night in the Seattle Center 
Coliseum. 

The Sonics avenged an earlier less in San Antonio with a 131-124 victory before 12,ITH fans 
The Sonics’ point aceummulation 

 set a season’s record for points tal­ lied in a gam e by Seattle. 
The victory was Seattle’s third in a row while the Spurs saw their two- game winning streak erased. 
Seattle also pushed its home record to 17-3. San Antonio has not won a game on the West Coast this season through four outings and its road record reads 4-16. 
The Sonics entered the final period with a 1o4-96 advantage and had little tro u b le m a in ta in in g th a t lead through the final 12 minutes. 

Now, the Spurs m ust quickly re­ group. They fly to Portland Saturday afternoon for a practice session in p rep a ra tio n for a Sunday night meeting with the Trail Blazers in the 
Portland Memorial Coliseum. 
The Sonics persistence finally paid off in the third period. 
Five minutes deep into the period 
Seattle grabbed its first lead of the game. 
Kookie Dennis Johnson started it bv collecting three points thanks to a 
Mike Gale foul. That cut the Spurs’ 

 lead to 8o-79. 
Johnson again responded with an inside shot second later to propel 
Seattle into an 81-8o lead. 
From that point, at o:45, the Sonics took control offensively and Moe was whistled for a technical foul because he felt the Sonics w ere g rab b in g throughout the quarter. 
Seattle built a couple of five-point advantages before Moe was tabbed by referee Jess Kersey for a technical at 2:12. Burleson took the toss but missed The Sonics were the owners 

 of a 97-92 lead at this point. 
At 1:5o the other referee, Michie 
P o w ers, sto p p ed the g a m e and warned Moo about his complaining. 
That stoppage of play brought an outburst from Sonic Coach Bill Bus­ sell. 
The Sonics held a 97-96 edge with 
1:31 remaining in the third period and then buried the Spurs with an offensive assault. 
S eattle had seven u n a n sw e re d points down to tin* end of the period 
One of those tallies was a Nick 

Weahterspoon toss which cam e off a 
Mack Calvin technical foul. 
Seattle shot about 55 per cent from the field in the third quarter com­ pared to the Spurs’ 5o per cent. Sonic guard Slick W atts led the scoring. with ll points in the period. Silas had seven for .San Antonio. 
Seattle got back in the gam e early in the second period. 
The Sonics blitzed the Spurs at the outset with seven unanswered points 

R ozelle mulls future o f draft 

LOS ANGELES (A P ) - 
C om m issioner Pete Rozelle said Friday that continuation of the college football draft de­ pends on the National Football 
League owners and the Players 
Association reaching a new basic agreement. 

The two sides have been negotiat­ ing for three Nears without success, and Rozelle said that until an under­ 

 standing can be reached, the college d ra ft, b a tte re d by re c e n t c o u rt rulings, cannot be held. 
“ Court decisions indicate that if player restric tio n s on freedom of movement, including the draft, are incorporated as part of a gen eral arm s-length bargaining agreem ent, it can be im m une from an ti-tru st challenge.” Rozelle said. 
“ The goal is to try to reach again a form of draft and option com pensa­ tion arrangem ent.” 
The N FL M an ag em en t Council, 

 bargaining agent for the owners, and the P layers Association have been talking continuously with little or no progress, but Rozelle rem ains opti­ mistic. 
“ We hope for an agreem ent this spring,” the commissioner said, "lf one c a n ’t be reached, the ow ners must weigh the business and legal aspects and m ake ap p ro p riate d e ­ cisions at that tim e." 
Rozelle said that if a draft is held. it will not follow th e fo rm a t of previous ones.

Son Antonio EXP R ESS-N EW S— 
Saturday January 8 I9 7 7 
P age sat9 errrr, stood it out 

LOS ANGELES — Well, it’s finally come down to this, Alan Page’s hemorrhoids. 
The physical condition of these two Super Bowl teams is so good visiting newsmen have been forced to scratch and search for fresh angles to report on each day. The most recent search took us to Mr. Page. 

The fierce Minnesota lineman wasn’t too fierce the other day as he sat out more than half a practice session. Or, to be more accurate, he stood it out. 
Seem s that P a g e ’s plan of preparation for this gam e calls for more Preparation H than anything else. Since the discovery of that semi-serious ailment we’ve been blitzed with bulietins on Alan’s condition. 
Viking Coach Bud Grant insists that Page is improving rapidly and “ most certainly’’ will play against Oakland 
Sunday. Alan leans in that direction too, although he did whip up a round of e x c ite m e n t late T h u rsd ay when, pressed by over-eager reporters, he conceded that it was 
“ possible” that he might sit this one out if his condition takes IO turns for the worst. Opps, did it again. Make that stand this one out. 

F rid ay G ra n t w atered down that story when he a n ­ nounced, “ the health of our team b ea rs no com m en t because we are in excellent condition, right at IOO per­ cen t.” Then he explained that P a g e ’s hemorrhoidal con­ dition “ has reduced” and that he’ll be okay. 
All of a sudden the weather becam e the hottest topic in town. 
Now the weather is something else, not nearly as good as 
P ag e’s problem. And it’s going to take more than a tube of ointment to cure this rainy condition. 
For the better part of three days rain has peppered this city of angels and late Thursday night a tremor tilted us a mite. Registered 3.ti on the Richter scale but in all proba­ bility only R ich ter noticed. Most ju st figured that Otis 

Sistrunk fell out of bed. 
Both Oakland and Minnesota personnel are praying for a 
•dry field Sunday and the weatherman says that there will be a IO percent chance of rain. Of course, looking to the brighter side, this m ean s that there will be 9o percent chance of sunshine. 
The w eatherman isn’t poking his neck out and laying any percentages on possible earthquakes Sunday. 
Rickies and F razier 

Those in charge of the care and l/andling of visiting newsmen really have been straining the past few days. 
They even brought Don Rickies by the press lounge to insult folks for a few hours. The veteran comic was in his finest form but most of his rem arks were a mite too stout for repeats in a family newspaper. 
Alan P a g e ’s hemorrhoids are one thing and R ick ies’ verbal zingers are something else. 
Then cam e Jo e Frazier, singing and dancing his way into our hearts. All of the fighter’s rem arks were clean and pure but Sm okin’ Jo e didn’t have an abundance of heavy com ments concerning the game. At one point he did mention that he has a few more friends on the Minnesota team so he’ll probably be rooting for the Vikes Sunday. 

Both Jo e and Rickies will be featured on a CBS live TV show tonight. Som ething billed like “ Super Saturday night,” designed to show how everyone is going bananas on the eve of Super Bowl XI. It’s assumed that a strong football flavor will be worked into the theme by non-player types. 
;; 
Visiting Franco Harris 

The press room appearances of Rickies and Frazier were promoted by CBS, of course, and designed only for the laziest reporters who were reluctant to leave the potato chip and dip counter in the hospitality lounge. There are many other, m ore football oriented subjects loose in the area and available for interviews for enterprising writers willing to chase a bit. 
For exam ple, I took an elevator I didn’t need to take just to ask F ran co Harris how it felt to sit out Pittsburgh’s last gam e because of an injury. I rode 14 flights to hear, 
“ m iserable, just m iserab le.” 
When I got back to the press room Rickies was sparring with Frazier. H e 'was winning, too, although no formal decision was announced. 
Y ou’ve got to move swiftly to keep track of everything going on out here. 

NATE A R C H IB A L D , injured N ew York Net guard, watches his team lose to Los Angeles 
Friday night, 85-82. A friend, Jean Claxton, sits with him. — AP Wirephoto

K auffm an m ade the re* sinner Bowie Kuhn.

Yankees. 

K a u f f m a n ’s r e m a r k s judging the egos of his col­ leagues were prefaced by the fact that they have in­ herited or made great sums of m oney and th at they should be gov ern ed by a strong commissioner.

Nuggets roar 

HOUSTON (A P ) - Denver Center 
Dan Issei scored 3o points, including 
21 in the second half to lead the 
Nuggets to a 117*1o7 National B a s ­ ketball Association victory over the 
Houston Rockets Friday night. 
The Nuggets, who lead the NBA's 
Midwest Division, never trailed in the contest, continually shutting off the Rockets with rugged defense.

LA N D O V E R . Md. (A P ) - Phil 
Chenier scored 26 points in the first three quarters to pace the W ashing­ ton B u llets to their fifth straig h t 
N atio n al B a s k e t b a l l A s s o c ia tio n victory, 99-89. over the slum ping 
Phoenix Suns Friday night.

Wednesday night’s victory over the 
New York Nets, matched that figure by sinking l l of 2o shots and adding six free throw s before d ep a rtin g midway through the final quarter.

Bullets built a 49-4o halftime edge, w idened it to 77-66 a f t e r t h r e e quarters and coasted to their 18th victory in 35 games.

Bulls bite 

CHICAGO (A P) - Wilbur Holland pumped in 24 points and and Mickey 
Johnson collected 2o points and 21 rebounds to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 198-88 triumph over the New York 
Knicks F rid ay night in a National 
Basketball Association gam e. 
Using a rugged defense and shut­ ting off the New York front line of 
Lonnie Shelton, Spencer Haywood and Bob McAdoo, the Bulls dealt New 
York its third straight defeat and lith road setback in 16 outings.

Pistons hot 

D E T R O IT (A P) - M L. Carr set a career scoring record and Chris Ford posted a new personal assist high as the Detroit Pistons won a free-for-all scoring battle from the Milwaukee 
Bucks, 14o-132, Friday night. 
It was the Pistons’ lith National 
Basketball Association victory in the last 15 games.

PH ILAD ELPH IA (A P) - George 
McGinnis scored 33 points, grabbed a ca reer high 22 rebounds and handed out seven assists as the Philadelphia 
76ers trounced the Cleveland Cava­ liers 116-96 in the National Basketball 
Association Friday night. 
The loss knocked the Cavaliers out of first place in the Central Division. 
T he 76ers raced to a 33-18 first- period lead and Cleveland never got closer than 13 points the rest of the gam e. It was 58-41 at halftime.

Lakers swept by the New York Nets 
85-82 in the National Basketball As­ sociation Friday night.

Free tackle book backfires 

Recent mail-stop orders issued by the U.S. 
Postal Service indicate that fishermen are only one-fifth as gullible as folks desiring to lose weight without really trying. 

U SP S has issued a mail-stop order against a New Jersey company called Angler’s Friend under the Postal False 
R ep resentation Statute for o fferin g for sale a book of 
“ secre ts” on “ How to Get F r e e Fishing T a ck le.” 
The firm asked $5.5o for an 18-page booklet which ad­ vised purchasers to write to fishing tackle m anufacturers offering to field test and evaluate specific fishing gear m ade by the m an u facturers. T hese letters, the booklet said, would result in a m inim um of $1oo worth of free tackle within the first mqnth. 

Upon investigation, the Postal Inspection Service disco­ vered that only one of the m anufacturers listed would even consider giving free tackle In exhange for field testing and then only after a personal interview. 

The Consumer Protection Office of the Postal Service 
Law Department filed a formal complaint charging that the firm falsely represented its product and engaged in a s ch e m e to o b tain m on ey th ro u g h the m a ils by false representations. 
Other mail-stop orders issued recen tly 'by U SP S were against five com panies for offering for sale such items as diet grapefruit pills, self-hypnosis tapes for weight loss and a w eigh t-red u cin g p ro g ra m called S lim Through 
Sleep. 
Learning it the hard way 

P ark s and Wildlife Departm ent information officer John 
O ’Dowd of San Antonio te lls about h is n e ig h b o r ’s 
16-year-old son who decided to trap for pelts to support his car. It was an expensive attem p t, but at least the exp erience taught the young a man the m eaning of 
“ playing possum .” 
T h e young trap p er ch eck ed his trap lin e the first morning and found he had caught two opossums. One was dead. T he other, a large male, was still alive, and the boy dispatched it with a sharp blow to the head. He put his possums on the floor of the back seat of his ca r and headed for home. 
Next thing he knew, the big m ale possum was trying to clim b into the front seat with the trapper. The boy grabbed it by the scruff of the neck and threw it into the back seat. 
The opossum appeared to be as dead as a door nail. 

He turned his attention back to driving, but only for a mom ent. Here cam e B re r Possum again, live as ever and twice as mean. This tim e the boy w asn't as fortunate. He broadsided another vehicle while trying to deal with what he m ust have thought was a possum with nine lives. 

“ After explaining his actions to a not very understand­ ing policeman, the other motorist and his father, he picked up the opossums and threw them in the tru n k ," John said. 
“ A tow truck cam e and hauled both cars to the garag e.” 
Late that afternoon, when he showed the car to a friend, he opened the trunk. The big opossum hopped out and ran off.

Saturday short shots 

Fishing guide Dave Hawk writes from El Fuerte in 
Mexico that the situation in that region is back to normal 
(and never was very far from it) since Lopez Portillo becam e president Dec. I. 
“ Elaine (Hawk’s wife) has been in and out of Mexico several tim es recently w itll nothing but good relations with all concerned,” he writes. “ To cap it all off. Governor 
Calderon of Sinaloa recently gave me permission for 12 new shotguns, eight of which were registered in El Fu erte 
Dec. 12.” 
“ Without exception, every custom er who has been to my place in Mexico will tell you that they were never treated better by the Mexican officials and authorities at Chihua­ hua or U erm otiUo,” he addds.

PER T H . Australia (A P ) 
— Am erican Catam aran champion Je rry King fin­ ished second in the second heat of National Hobie 16 sailing championship on 
Melville water Friday. But 
King. who won the first heat Thursday, is leading the series with a loss of only three points. 
The only other American competing, Don Altmans of 
Los Angeles, finished fifth. 
Friday's heat was won by- 
Perth skipper Kevin Ager.

Marcos while! A & I (6-3) tackles Angelo# State (6-4) at Kingsville.

Son Antonio EXPRESS-N EW S— Soturdoy January 8 1977 
H 

K ra m e r in action 

FO R R EST G REGO 
. . . North coach 

M O BILE. Ala. (A P ) — Sixty-three col­ lege football seniors, including six All- 
Americans, suit up for their first play-for* pay game Saturday in the 28th annual 
Senior Bow l 
Because the players are paid $l,o(Ml-plus for their efforts, the contest is not sanc­ tioned by the National Collegiate Athletic 
Association—but is. in a way, by the pros. 
Already more than 2oo observers from professional football teams, including 15 head coaches, have been talent-hunting raiibirds at the intermittent Iv wet. cold 
Senior Bowl drills. 
Getting up-close looks were N FL Coach of 
Hie Year Forrest Gregg of the Cleveland 
Browns and Don Shuls of the Miami Dol­ phins. Gregg is at the helm of the North team, Simla the South 
The South has the edge in All-Americans. 
Along with Rice quarterback Tommy 

Kramer, the South All-Americans are of­ fensive linem en T .J 
H um phries of 
Arkansas State and Mike W ilson of Geor­ gia. defensive lineman Eddie Edwards of 
Miami, Fla., and linebacker Robert Jack ­ son of Texas A&M. 
And while the South has an instant aerial game ii. the person of Kramer, who com­ pleted more than half of his ahi passes this season, Simla also says he has been im­ pressed with his runners—Terry Rnbiskie of LSI . Calvin Culliver of Alabama and 
Tun Wilson of Maryland 

There’ll be no campus rah rah after the game, but there will in' substantial pocket money 
Winners get paid $1,5oo, losers 
$1,25o. The most valuable player drives away in a free automobile, and the two top plovers on ('ach team pad their bankroll with an extra $2,5oo award.

Dint rift 31-AAA A 

The long drouth is over for Harlandale, there is joy in 
Indianian^. 
The Indians ended a 54-game losing streak Friday night with a 4o-42 victory on their own court over South San 
Antonio in the teams’ District 29-AAAA opener. 
Leading the way for Harlandale were Roland De La 
W heatley, 67-42 
Garza with 17 points and David Pena with 12 as the Indians took the lead in the waning minutes and held on. 
Harlandale had lost its last start in 1974-75, all 33 games last season and the first 2o this winter. 
In two big boys’ games that marked other loop openers, 
Kennedy won a o2-58 count over Jay in District 3o-AAA A, while in 32-AAAA, Leo outscored MacArthur by IO in the final stanza for a 78-68 verdict.

2415 HARRY WURZBACH 

UTHMAN ROAD 

S l o c u m to stay at A & M 

COLLEGE 
STATION, 
Tex. (AP) - R.C. Slocum, defensive ends coach at 
Texas A&M, said Friday that he will stay at Texas 
A&M rather than join Lou 
Holtz’s new football staff at 
Arkansas. 
On Thursday, Slocum told A&M Head Coach 
Emory Bellard that he was going to Arkansas and no­ tified Holtz of his decision. 
Slocum, who was to be defensive line coach at z\r- kansas, said he changed his mind because “ it makes no sense for me to leave when our program has reached such a successful stage,” 
Texas A&M was 1o-2 the past two seasons after be­ ing only 3-8 five years ago when he joined the staff. 
Aussie paces ski duels 

 g a r m is c h -p a r t e n k u 
CHEN. West Germany 
(AP) 
Austria’s Franz 
Klammer was nearly two seconds faster than his ri vats Friday in training for the season’s third World 
Cup downhill race Satur day. 
Klammer, the Olympic gold medalist who won both downhills this season, clocked 2 minutes, o 9H se­ conds on the 3,32o meter 
Kandahar course that drops 
92o meters through 32 gates. 
Cmpires to meet 

The monthly meeting of the ban Antonio A S A 
Umpires Association will be held at 9 a in Sunday at 
San Fernando Gym. Of fleers are asked to be there at 7 45 a rn. Applications for membership will be ac cepted at the meeting.

Thousands visit huge auto plant 

DODGE’S customized w arlock pickup truck features real oak sideboards. O ak buttons cover screw heads to give the sideboards an all-oak exterior 
Dodge finds wood som ething special 

SPACIAL TO THS EXPRESS-NEWS 
DETROIT — When Dodge truck purchasing people start­ ed to buy the oak for the side­ boards of the new W arlock pickup trucks, they soon found out that wood is som ething special. 
I f s not like m a n u fa c tu re d p ro ­ d u cts, such as ste e l, ru b b e r and plastic, that m ake up the bulk of their purchases. Since very little wood is used in today’s trucks, they had ai­ rn o«l no ex p erien ce in buying the m aterial. 
By the tim e they had lined up en­ ough top q u a lity oak for a run of 
Warlock models during the 1977 m o­ del year, the purchasing people were glad they w eren’t on the lob 5o years ago. 

"If you don't buy up the oak when it is available, you can miss the b o a t' 
• 
IIM 
I " 
...— 
- 
In those days when wood w as used extensively in car and truck produc­ tion, it was purchased by the boxcar load — as many as l(M) of them at a time. 
“ What we needed only am ounted to two or three railcar loads," explained 
Bernard F Knotek, m anager of truck and equipm ent planning for Chrysler 
Corporation’s U.S. Automotive Sales 
Division. 
"However, since we were dealing with a product of M other N ature, we had to be careful with our planning. 

"If you don’t buy up the oak you are going to need when it’s available, you 

 can m iss the boat. Once a m ill is sold out, it may not be able to ship you any oak for another two or three months. 
" T h e re is no w ay you can w ait three m onths for parts to come out of the pipeline and still m eet the truck in d u s try ’s m a ss p ro d u ctio n schedules." 

Slats for W arlock sideboards are milled to the proper size. After a de­ corative pattern is cut in the slats, they are attached to the stakes which will link them to the cargo boxes of 
D-1oo and W-1oo pickups from Dodge. 

Slats are attached to the stakes with m etal screw s. Oak buttons go over th e screw h ead s to give th e sideboards an all-oak exterior. F in ­ ishing the wood is the final step be­ fore the sideboards are installed. 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPftESS-NEWS 
DEARBORN, Mich. — The 
Ford Motor Ct). Guest Center here is a national crossroads and an international mecca as visitors arrive daily for a tour of the famous Rouge manufac­ turing complex. 
B usloads of Boy Scouts from Du­ buque, sari-clad Indians from Cal­ cutta. a babe in arm s from Detroit, and a folk dance troupe from Russia ty p ify the v a rie ty of p eo p le and g roups that daily converge on the 
Guest Center. 
The m ajority of these visitors come from M ichigan, nearby sta te s and 
C anada, but a larg e n u m b e r also com e from M a s sa c h u se tts. New 
York, C alifornia and Florida. More than H.(MM) visitors annually come from Japan, Israel, India, Great B ri­ tain and Germ any. 
All ages 

What draw s people of all ages, in­ te re s ts , and b a c k g ro u n d s to th is place? 
“ M ainly, the opportunity to view the dynam ic developm ent of tile au­ tom obile as it evolves, step-by-step, from molten steel to a quality-tested' c a r," says Special E vents M anager 
David Dowling. 
The Guest Conter becom es the gateway to that opportunity, ll is in addition an advance attraction with its scores of interesting faces to be seen But perhaps m ore im portant to travelers — it is the w aystation to the 
Rouge. 
On arriv in g at the G uest C enter, which is located across from Henry 
F ord M useum and G reen field V il­ lage. visitors are asked to sign in at one of the registration pedestals lo­ cated about the main lobby. 
In the brief wait for the next tour bus, guests have an opportunity to get behind th e wheel of the latest 
Ford car and truck models, follow the history of Ford cars on a video-tape player, or view the com pany s D ear­ born test tra c k from an a ttrac tiv e display balcony. 
Tourist facility 

T his com fortable and inviting set­ ting has more than fulfilled the pur­ pose for which it was built in 1974. In fac t, D ow ling c re d its th e G uest 
C enter with boosting the num ber of sum m er visitors by 2o per cent d u r­ ing its first year. 
A m odern brick and g lass stru c ­ tu re, the G uest C enter rep laces to som e ex ten t th e h isto ric R otunda which was destroyed by fire in 19o2. 

VISITORS watch as Ford w orker prepares to unite the body of a M ustang ll with its chassis on the assem bly line 
It had served as Ford s tourist fa­ cility for popular seasonal exhibitions as well as the Rouge tour al varying tim es since 1936. 
The first Rouge tour was taken in 
1928, when 32 persons were allowed to v isit F o rd ’s D e a rb o rn A ssem b ly 
P lan t and o th e r fa c ilitie s th en standing on the banks of the Rouge 
River. 
Fifty years later, over six million people had ta k e n th e to u r of th** l,2(Mi-acre complex and its extensive operations. 
A typical tour b e g in s with a free bus ride from the Guest C enter to the 
Rouge complex. 
During this short trip, young tour guides o r v e tera n g u e st re la tio n s 

 representatives d escrib e Ford faci­ lities seh‘11 along the way. 
They relate historical and statisti­ cal facts about Ford and the Rouge complex. 
O nce th e to u r b u s is in sid e th e 
Rouge gate, visitors get an overview of th e v ast co m p lex : n u m e ro u s plants, hung blast furnaces and coke ovens, w arehouses and storage bins, and m o u n d s of iro n o re p e lle ts against m iles of train cars and rails, acres of p ark in g lots and m assiv e ships unloading th eir carg o in the 
Rouge Boat Slip. 
The first stop on the two-hour tour is the com puterized Hot S trip Mill

NORTH CENTRAL FORD

 k t 
I 

San Antonio E X P RESS-N EW S— 
Saturday January 8 I £ 7 7 Assembly line tour is popular 

Ufo * i 
A RO U G E PLA N T v is ito r finds a q u ie t co rn er fo r em ­ broidering in Ford’s G u est C en ter a t D earb o rn, M ich. 
— XDKHfeSW9r»io>tIY 

Continued from Page I where thick steel slabs are converted to coiled sheets every two minutes. * 
Visitors are guided over catw alks1 that look down upon giant furnaces that turn out slab after slab of fiery steel. 
Children and oldsters alike look on in awe as the :i2-foot-long slabs are reheated and repeatedly elongated until they are half-mile-long sheets of steel. 
Second stage 
The second stage of the tour takes visitors to the Dearborn Assembly 
Plant where they see the Mustang ll being assembled. They are led by the tour guides along the assembly line, seeing the timed, precise interplay of man and machine on the production line. 
Over the years, the Rouge complex has become a “ must see" in the De­ troit area. Guest Center representa­ tives point out. Visitors often plan their vacations around a stop at the— 
Rouge or make trips just to take the tour, they say. 
That interest grew even more dur­ ing the mid-seventies when Ameri­ cans got into the Bicentennial spirit and became more interested in what their country had to offer, noted 
Dowling. 
“ I ’d known about the tour since 

A typical tour begins with a free bus ride from the 
Guest Center to the Rouge complex 

 a u t o m o t i v e d i s p c a s 

 grade school, but this was my first chance to take it,” said an electrical engineer visiting from Lexington, 
Mass. In Detroit on company busi­ ness, he and a fellow engineer took advantage of a break in their work to visit the Ford facility. 
A Brooklyn, N.Y., homemaker and her sister-in-law, an osteopath from 
London, England, made a point to take the tour at the urging of rela­ tives in Detroit. 
“ They told us so much about it that we were interested in seeing it for ourselves,” the visitors said. 
Sales people 
Local residents who have made the tour are perhaps the best sales people for it. They often include the Rouge tour in their plans for entertaining visiting family and friends. 
For one Detroit rabbi, the tour was, the first attraction he thought about. for his two brothers visiting him*! from Rochester, N Y 
“ The Rouge complex has such an outstanding name as something in­ teresting in Detroit,” the rabbi said. 
A native of Germany living tem­ porarily in suburban Detroit included 

 the tour on the itinerary for friends visiting from her homeland 
“ I liked it so much, and I found the steel mill operations particularly in­ teresting,” she said. 
It was the third tour for the visitor from Marlton, N .J., who takes time out from most of his visits with his brother to see the Ford complex. 
The New Jersey man said he had taken a particular interest in the Hot 
Strip M ill operations, with an an eye toward possibly entering some type of engineering in that area. 
Major stop 
In many cases, a trip to the mam­ moth Rouge complex with its diver­ sified operations is a major stop in some travelers’ planned visits to in­ dustrial plants around the country. 
“ We just like to see things, and we especially like to tour the plants in various cities,” said a woman from 
Salem, Ind. It was a second visit for the homemaker who first toured the complex in the 196o’s. 
Often parents see such industrial tours as a way of bringing the social studies book to life for their children. 
. , A family en route to their new 

 nome in Los Agates, Calif., took time out to stop over in Detroit so that their daughter could take the tour. 
On a good number of days, the tour not only offers a lesson in industrial development, but also presents the chance to see and talk with visitors from other lands. 
A visit by the Moiseyev Dancers — a folk dance troupe from Russia that performed at nearby Pine Knob Mu­ sic Theatre — was typical of the in­ ternational groups that regularly take the tour. 

4o,ooo guests 

Some special visiting groups, whose members total nearly 4o,OOO guests in an average year, have also included the crew and officers of the 
French destroyer Le Du Perre, the 
Swedish hockey team, army officers from Saudi Arabia, the World Press 
Institute and the Philippine olympic team, to name a few. 
Special dignitaries and their parties have included King Gustav of 
Sweden, and E iji Toyoda and Soi- chiro Honda, top officials of the Ja ­ panese auto industry. 
V isitors have in general been keenly interested in the vast facilities and the different operations they see on the Rouge tour.

Double Bonus Ads w ill deliver results at Texas Steed Savings of 6 o % These ads are exposed to 2 9 3 ,o o o potential buyers Doily in the Son Antonio W ont Ad Superm arket (3 3 ,o o o more thon the lig h t)

Est. 1949 

SECRETARY 

Swearingen Aviation has an immediate requirement for a highly skilled Secretary for the product support dept. Duties re­ quire excellent typing and shorthand, the ability to organize the administrative de­ tails of the dept, plus the ability to com ­ municate effectively. Bilingual ability pre­ ferred. The position provides stable em­ ployment, good starting salary and excel­ lent fringe benefits. Interested applicants should apply in person, Personnel Office, 
Swearingen Aviation, International Air­ port, San Antonio, Tx. (come East on Bit­ ters Road past Blossom Athletic Center, turn right at N E entrance road to Sw ear­ ingen.)

STAFF PHARM ACISTS

•qual opportunity employer 

DIRECTOR OF NURSING SERVICES 

Challenging opportunity for experienced Nurs­ ing Director or Assistant Director, to assume duties of Director of Nursing Services in 136 bed general acute care community hospital, located in Kingsville, TX. This position offers the op­ portunity to implement new procedures and your inovative ideas. Excellent salary and benefits. Send resume, with salary history, to: 
A.E. 
Devine, Administrator, 
Kleberg 
County
